Арина Родионова |image = Rodionova Ar. RG15 (16) (18684261454).jpg |fullname = Arina Ivanovna Rodionova |country = {{Flag|Russia}} (2004–2014)
{{Flag|Australia}} (2014–present) |residence = [[Melbourne]], Australia |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=first|1989|12|15}} |birth_place = [[Tambov]], Soviet Union |height = {{height|m=1.68}} |turnedpro = 2004[http://rodionova.com/arina-rodionova/ Official Biography] of Arina Rodionova |plays = Right (two-handed backhand) |careerprizemoney = $1,118,860 |website = [http://rodionova.com/ rodionova.com] |singlesrecord = 365–325 |singlestitles = 8 [[International Tennis Federation|ITF]] |highestsinglesranking = 116 (23 October 2017) |currentsinglesranking = 161 (2 July 2018) |AustralianOpenresult = 1R ([[2011 Australian Open – Women's Singles|2011]], [[2015 Australian Open – Women's Singles|2015]], [[2017 Australian Open - Women's Singles|2017]]) |FrenchOpenresult = 1R ([[2016 French Open – Women's Singles|2016]]) |Wimbledonresult = 2R ([[2017 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles|2017]]) |USOpenresult = 2R ([[2017 US Open – Women's Singles|2017]]) |doublesrecord = 337-237 |doublestitles = 29 ITF |highestdoublesranking = 41 (27 July 2015) |currentdoublesranking = 95 (26 March 2018) |AustralianOpenDoublesresult = QF ([[2016 Australian Open – Women's Doubles|2016]]) |FrenchOpenDoublesresult = 3R ([[2015 French Open – Women's Doubles|2015]]) |WimbledonDoublesresult = 2R ([[2011 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles|2011]], [[2014 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles|2014]], [[2015 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles|2015]], [[2018 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Doubles|2018]]) |USOpenDoublesresult = 1R ([[2010 US Open – Women's Doubles|2010]], [[2015 US Open - Women's Doubles|2015]], [[2016 US Open - Women's Doubles|2016]], [[2017 US Open - Women's Doubles|2017]]) |Mixed = yes |mixedtitles = |AustralianOpenMixedresult = 1R ([[2014 Australian Open – Mixed Doubles|2014]], [[2015 Australian Open – Mixed Doubles|2015]], [[2016 Australian Open – Mixed Doubles|2016]], [[2017 Australian Open – Mixed Doubles|2017]], [[2018 Australian Open – Mixed Doubles|2018]]) |FrenchOpenMixedresult = |WimbledonMixedresult = 1R ([[2015 Wimbledon Championships – Mixed Doubles|2015]]) |USOpenMixedresult = |Team = yes |FedCupresult = 0-2 |updated = 21 October 2018 }} '''Arina Ivanovna Rodionova''' ({{lang-ru|Арина Ивановна Родионова}}; born 15 December 1989 in [[Tambov]]) is a [[Russians in Australia|Russian-born Australian]] [[tennis]] player. Rodionova has won nine singles and 29 doubles titles on the [[ITF Women's Circuit]]. In 2007, she won the [[2007 Australian Open|Australian Open]] girls' doubles title, partnering [[Evgeniya Rodina]]. On 23 October 2017, she reached her career-high singles ranking of world No. 116. On 27 July 2015, she peaked at No. 41 in the doubles rankings. Elder sister [[Anastasia Rodionova|Anastasia]] is also a tennis professional, and the two sisters have intermittently contested doubles tournaments with modest success. Their most notable achievement as a team came at the [[2010 Malaysian Open – Doubles|2010 Malaysian Open]], in which they reached the final before losing to [[Chan Yung-jan]] and [[Zheng Jie]] in a super tie-break. ==Personal life== [[File:Arina Rodionova.jpg|thumb|left|252px|Rodionova in 2010]] Arina Rodionova was born to Ivan and Natalia Rodionova and lives in [[Melbourne]] with her sister Anastasia.[http://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/11166 WTA Tour | Players | Info (Biography) | Arina Rodionova] She began playing tennis aged three, "I began playing tennis when I was almost three years old. And why exactly tennis? There wasn't any choice for me with my dad being a coach and my sister a professional tennis player, but in the end I think it's worked well!" Rodionova cites [[Martina Hingis]] as her role model, and also admires [[Justine Henin]] and [[Bob and Mike Bryan]]. She prefers hard courts and [[forehand]] as a shot. Rodionova received Australian citizenship in January 2014 and married [[Australian rules football]]er [[Ty Vickery]] in December 2015.http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/tennis/article-3366847/Arina-Rodionova-wins-Australian-Open-wild-card-qualifier-11am-marries-Aussie-Rules-player-Ty-Vickery-five-hours-later.html ==Career== Rodionova made her debut as a professional in 2004 at an [[International Tennis Federation|ITF]] event in [[Protvino]], Russia. In 2005, she won a title in [[Minsk]], followed by another win in Moscow the following year. In 2008, she finished as a runner-up in an ITF event in [[Istanbul]]. In 2009, Rodionova won two ITF titles in singles and eight in doubles. In 2010, Rodionova defeated [[Jarmila Groth]] in the final of a $25,000 tournament in [[Burnie]]. In doubles, she advanced to the final of the [[Women's Tennis Association|WTA]]-level [[2010 Malaysian Open|Malaysian Open]] with her sister Anastasia. Although they defeated No. 1 seeds [[Alisa Kleybanova]] and [[Yan Zi (tennis)|Yan Zi]] along the way, the sisters lost the final match to Chan Yung-jan and Zheng Jie in close three sets. At the [[2011 Australian Open – Women's Singles|2011 Australian Open]], Rodionova equalled her career-best showing at a Grand Slam tournament by qualifying for the main draw. She lost in the first round to fellow qualifier [[Anne Keothavong]], 5–7, 4–6. She then won a [[2011 Strabag Prague Open|$50,000 event]] in May in Prague, partnering [[Darya Kustova]]. She qualified for the [[2011 Aegon Classic|Aegon Classic]], and won her first-round match against [[Virginie Razzano]]. She then notched the biggest win of her career by defeating No. 1 seed and world No. 16 [[Kaia Kanepi]] in the second round. She lost to the 14th seed [[Magdaléna Rybáriková]] in the third round. At [[2011 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]], Rodionova barely missed out on qualifying for the main draw by losing to [[Kristýna Plíšková]] in three sets. She achieved very modest results through much of the rest of the year, losing in the first or second round of most tournaments she entered. [[File:ARINA RODIONOVA (11902588904).jpg|thumb|left|252px|Rodionova in 2014]] In 2012, Rodionova lost in the qualifying rounds of the [[2012 Apia International Sydney|Apia International Sydney]] and the [[2012 Australian Open|Australian Open]]. She then lost in the quarterfinals of a $25,000 event in [[2012 McDonald's Burnie International|Burnie]]. She then competed in two more ITF events – losing in the second and first round, respectively. She picked up form in ITF Mildura, reaching the semifinals. Rodionova then competed in three more tournaments, losing in the second round of all three. She then failed to qualify in [[2012 e-Boks Open|Copenhagen]]. Her best result of the year came at the WTA clay event [[2012 Grand Prix SAR La Princesse Lalla Meryem|Grand Prix SAR La Princesse Lalla Meryem]]. She defeated [[Darija Jurak]], [[Karolína Plíšková]], and world No. 108 [[Mathilde Johansson]] to qualify for the main draw. Each match lasted three sets. She took on [[Timea Bacsinszky]] in the first round, started well by winning the first set 6–2, but was forced to retire due a severe wrist injury she sustained while trailing 0–4 in the second set. She was also forced to withdraw from the doubles competition, where she and Anastasia were the No. 1 seeds. She missed a big part of the clay-court season to recover from the injury. Rodionova returned in July; she was only able to make it past the first round in one of five ITF tournaments. However, she had a great result in [[2012 Party Rock Open|Las Vegas]], where she reached the semifinals. Following three more early exits in tournaments, she reached the final of a $25,000 event in [[Traralgon]], and followed this up by winning her next tournament in [[Bendigo]]. She finished the year with two more early-round losses in [[Toyota]] and [[Dubai]]. ===World TeamTennis=== In 2011, Rodionova was drafted by the [[Washington Kastles]] WTT Team, coached by [[Murphy Jensen]]. As a result of their 14-match win undefeated regular season, the Kastles secured the top seed in the Conference Championships where they beat the Boston Lobsters. In the WTT Finals the Kastles defeated the St. Louis Aces to capture the 2011 WTT Championship for the second time in its four-year existence, completing the first ever 16–0 season in WTT 36-year history. revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Ben Sasse |image = Ben Sasse official portrait.jpg |jr/sr = United States Senator |state = [[Nebraska]] |alongside = [[Deb Fischer]] |term_start = January 3, 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Mike Johanns]] |successor = |order1 = 15th |title1 = [[Chancellor (education)|President]] of [[Midland University]] |term_start1 = December 10, 2010 |term_end1 = December 31, 2014 |predecessor1 = Stephen Fritz |successor1 = Jody Horner |office2 = [[Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Planning and Evaluation]] |president2 = [[George W. Bush]] |term_start2 = December 19, 2007 |term_end2 = January 20, 2009 |predecessor2 = Michael O'Grady |successor2 = Sherry Glied |birth_name = Benjamin Eric Sasse |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|2|22}} |birth_place = [[Plainview, Nebraska|Plainview]], [[Nebraska]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = Melissa McLeod |children = 3 |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |education = [[Harvard University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe)|St. John's College, Maryland]]
([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[Yale University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) |website = {{url|sasse.senate.gov/|Senate website}} }} '''Benjamin Eric Sasse''' ({{IPAc-en|pron|ˈ|s|æ|s}} {{respell|SASS|'}};Walton, Don. [http://journalstar.com/news/local/ben-sasse-getting-to-know-you/article_636976ea-a958-5d07-bcc0-06fff4fb4ce4.html "Ben Sasse: Getting to know you".] [http://journalstar.com/ ''Lincoln Journal Star''.] June 10, 2013. Retrieved 2013-11-22. born February 22, 1972) is an American politician, author, professor, consultant, and educational administrator from the U.S. state of [[Nebraska]]. In [[United States Senate election in Nebraska, 2014|2014]], he was elected to a seat in the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]]. Sasse is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. Born in [[Plainview, Nebraska]], Sasse earned a doctorate in American history from [[Yale University]]. He taught at the [[University of Texas]] and served as an Assistant Secretary in the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]].https://www.congress.gov/nomination/110th-congress/809?q=%7B"search"%3A%5B"Michael+O%27Grady"%5D%7D&r=3 In 2010, he was named president of [[Midland University]] in [[Fremont, Nebraska]]. In 2014, he successfully ran for a vacant seat in the U.S. Senate, defeating [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nominee [[David Domina]] by a margin of 65% to 31%.{{cite web|title=National election results 2014|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dre/politics/election-results-2014?office=senate&state=31|website=Washington Post|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} ==Early life== Sasse was born on February 22, 1972, in [[Plainview, Nebraska]], the son of Gary Lynn Sasse, a high school teacher and football coach, and Linda Sasse.Mirza, Anzish. [https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-04-24/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-ben-sasse "10 Things You Didn't Know About Ben Sasse".] [https://www.usnews.com/ ''U.S. News & World Report''.] April 24, 2017. Retrieved October 21, 2017. He graduated from [[Fremont Senior High School (Nebraska)|Fremont Senior High School, Fremont, Nebraska]] in 1990Sasse, Benjamin, [http://permanent.access.gpo.gov/FDLP1431/51199.pdf "Biographical Information"] Appendix to Hearing re Nomination of Dr. Benjamin Sasse, pp. 78–84. U.S. House. Committee on the Finance. Washington: Government Printing Office; retrieved January 11, 2014. and was [[valedictorian]] of his class.{{cite news|last1=Roth|first1=Zachary|title=Ben Sasse, GOP senator, leads #NeverTrump movement|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/ben-sasse-gop-senator-leads-nevertrump-movement|accessdate=May 5, 2016|publisher=MSNBC}} Sasse graduated from [[Harvard University]] in 1994 with a bachelor's degree in government. He also studied at the [[University of Oxford]] during the fall of 1992 on a junior year abroad program. In 1998, Sasse obtained a [[Master of Arts in Liberal Studies]] from the Graduate Institute at [[St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe)|St. John's College]]. He also obtained [[Master of Arts]], [[Master of Philosophy]], and [[Ph.D]] degrees in history from [[Yale University]]. Sasse's [[doctoral dissertation]], "The Anti-[[Madalyn Murray O'Hair|Madalyn]] Majority: Secular Left, Religious Right, and the Rise of Reagan's America", won the Theron Rockwell Field{{cite web|url=http://secretary.yale.edu/services-resources/lectureships-fellowships-prizes/porter-and-field|title=Theron Rockwell Field and the John Addison Porter prize competitions|website=Yale University|access-date=July 2, 2017}} and George Washington Egleston{{cite web|url=http://secretary.yale.edu/department/george-washington-egleston-1901|title=George Washington Egleston (1901)|website=Yale University|access-date=July 2, 2017}} Prizes.[http://history.yale.edu/academics/graduate-program/dissertations-year/dissertations-year-2000-2009 "Dissertations By Year"], Yale.edu; retrieved January 11, 2014. ==Early career== From September 1994 to November 1995, Sasse worked as an associate consultant at the management consulting firm [[Boston Consulting Group]]. For the next year, he served as consultant/executive director for Christians United For Reformation (CURE). During his tenure, CURE merged with the [[Alliance of Confessing Evangelicals]] (ACE), and Sasse became executive director of ACE in Anaheim, California. Maruina, Todd, [http://www.iclnet.org/pub/resources/text/reformed/archive96/nr96-048.txt "Conference of Top Evangelical Leaders Calls Evangelical Movement to Repentance for Liberal Theological Drifts"]. United Reformed News Service, May 21, 2006; retrieved January 12, 2014. From January 2004 to January 2005, Sasse served as chief of staff for the U.S. [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] [[Office of Legal Policy]] in Washington, D.C. and as a part-time assistant professor at the [[University of Texas at Austin]], commuting to Austin to teach. Sasse left the Department of Justice to serve as chief of staff to Representative [[Jeff Fortenberry]] (R-Nebr.) from January 2005 to July 2005. Sasse then advised the U.S. [[Department of Homeland Security]] in Washington, D.C., on national security issues from July to September 2005 as a consultant. He moved to [[Austin, Texas]], to resume his professorship full-time from September 2005 to December 2006. From December 2006 to December 2007, Sasse served as counselor to the secretary at the [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS) in Washington, D.C., where he advised the secretary on a broad spectrum of health policy issues, from healthcare access to food safety and security.{{Cite web|url=http://www.statelegislativeroundtable.org/clc/downloads/2015-Freshman-Healthbook.pdf|title=The 114th Congress Freshman Healthbook 2015 - A Guide to Congress' New Healthcare Policy Makers|year=2015|editor-last=Woodbury|editor-first=Anne|website=TogoRun|location=Washington, D.C., USA|page=9|access-date=July 2, 2017}} In July 2007, Sasse was nominated by President [[George W. Bush]] to the post of assistant secretary for planning and evaluation in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[https://aspe.hhs.gov/report/performance-improvement-2008 "Evaluation: Performance Improvement 2008"], hhs.gov; retrieved February 19, 2015.[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/07/20070726-7.html "Personnel Announcement"], White House archives; retrieved January 12, 2014. His appointment was confirmed by the Senate in December 2007[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/cpquery/13?&sid=cp111jSzSD&refer=&r_n=sr013.111&db_id=111&item=13&&sid=cp111jSzSD&r_n=sr013.111&hd_count=50&item=13&&sel=TOC_216682& "Report on the Activities of the Committee on Finance During the 110th Congress"]. Committee Report 13 of 50, Senate Report 111-013. United States Senate; retrieved January 12, 2014. and he served until the end of the Bush administration, in January 2009. During his tenure at HHS, Sasse took an unpaid leave from the University of Texas. During 2009, Sasse advised private equity clients and health care investors and taught at the [[University of Texas]].K. Weems & B. Sasse, [https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB123966918025015509 "Is Government Health Insurance Cheap?"], ''Wall Street Journal''; retrieved January 11, 2014.Sen. John Cornyn (R-TX) & Benjamin Sasse, [https://www.forbes.com/2009/09/08/health-care-debate-reform-polls-opinions-contributors-speech.html "Do Healthcare Reformers Fear A Reading Public?"], Forbes.com; retrieved January 11, 2011. In October 2009, he officially joined the [[University of Texas]] [[LBJ School of Public Affairs]]' Center for Politics and Governance as a fellow, before being appointed president of Midland University.[http://www.utexas.edu/lbj/cpg/news_detail.php?id=9 "LBJ School of Public Affairs Professor Ben Sasse Joins Center for Politics and Governance As Fellow"]. University of Texas; retrieved January 12, 2014. ==Midland University== Sasse was announced as the 15th president of [[Midland University|Midland Lutheran College]] (now Midland University) in October 2009. At age 37, he was one of the youngest chief executives in American higher education when he took over leadership of the 128-year-old institution in the spring of 2010. Sasse's grandfather, Elmer Sasse, worked for Midland for 33 years, mainly as vice president of finance. The school was experiencing financial and academic difficulties; Sasse has been credited with "turn(ing) it around," rebranding "Midland Lutheran College" as Midland University, instituting new policies (including spot quizzes and class attendance), and "prodigious fundraising."{{cite news|last1=Hampson|first1=Rick|title=Ben Sasse, the Senate GOP's 'Never Trumper,' irks some voters at home|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/06/06/ben-sasse-nebraska-republicans-donald-trump/85497064/|accessdate=June 9, 2016|publisher=USA Today|date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Buffington|first1=Tracy|title=Sasse reflects on his five years at Midland|url=http://fremonttribune.com/news/local/sasse-reflects-on-his-five-years-at-midland/article_89400f66-fb9d-5353-a6da-141498a28560.html|accessdate=May 25, 2016|publisher=[[Fremont Tribune]]|date=January 3, 2015}} Sasse was officially installed as president on December 10, 2010.[http://www.midlandu.edu/office-president "Office of the President".] [http://www.midlandu.edu/ Midland University.] Retrieved June 13, 2013. When he was appointed, enrollment was at a historic low and the college was "on the verge of bankruptcy."{{cite news|last1=Ricker|first1=Steven|title=Sasse to resign from Midland at year's end|url=http://fremonttribune.com/news/local/sasse-to-resign-from-midland-at-year-s-end/article_1305d916-015e-5bc2-8349-978dd45dd247.html|accessdate=May 25, 2016|publisher=Fremont Tribune|date=May 22, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Buffington|first1=Tracy|title=Sen. Sasse looks back on 5 years at Midland University|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jan/10/sen-sasse-looks-back-on-5-years-at-midland-univers/?page=all|accessdate=May 25, 2016|publisher=Washington Times|date=January 10, 2016}} During his tenure as president, enrollment grew from 590 to 1,300 students.{{cite news|last1=Walton|first1=Don|title=Getting to Know Ben sasse|url=http://fremonttribune.com/news/local/getting-to-know-ben-sasse/article_7d92e233-4eb6-5d2d-ae84-b753049e0daf.html|accessdate=May 25, 2016|publisher=Lincoln Start Journal|date=June 10, 2013}} When nearby [[Dana College]] was forced to close, Sasse managed to hire much of the faculty and enable most of the students to transfer to Midland. When Sasse announced his intention to run for U.S. Senate, he offered to resign his post at Midland. Instead, the Board asked him to stay at Midland under a partial leave of absence;Moring, Roseann. [http://www.omaha.com/article/20140407/NEWS/140408898 "Ben Sasse says he can whip government into shape"], omaha.com; retrieved April 8, 2014. in October 2013, his employment contract was amended to reduce his remuneration.[https://efdsearch.senate.gov/search/home United States Senate Financial Disclosures], United States Senate website; retrieved January 11, 2014. Sasse stepped down as president of Midland on December 31, 2014.https://www.midlandu.edu/groundbreaking-president-resign ==U.S. Senate== ===2014 election=== {{main|United States Senate election in Nebraska, 2014}} In October 2013, Sasse announced his candidacy for the United States Senate seat occupied by Republican [[Mike Johanns]], who was not running for reelection.Tysver, Robynn. [http://www.omaha.com/article/20131007/NEWS/131008952/1685 "If Obamacare survives, U.S. won't, Ben Sasse says as he officially launches Senate bid"], omaha.com; retrieved October 17, 2013. As of October 2013, his fundraising total of nearly $815,000 from individual donors in his first quarter broke Nebraska's previous record of $526,000 from individual donors, set in 2007 by Johanns while he was the U.S. Secretary of Agriculture.{{cite news|last=Tysver|first=Robynn|title=Donors spread funds across Senate race, though Ben Sasse far ahead of other candidates|url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20131015/NEWS/131019196/1016|accessdate=October 17, 2013|newspaper=Omaha World Herald}} Upon announcing his candidacy, Sasse expressed strong opposition to the [[Affordable Care Act]]. His primary opponent, [[Shane Osborn]], questioned the depth of Sasse's opposition to the ACA, publicizing articles and speeches Sasse delivered during and after the act's passage through Congress; according to the ''Omaha World-Herald'', "Osborn's campaign appears intent on questioning whether Sasse is a true conservative."Burnett, James R. [http://www.omaha.com/article/20131125/NEWS/131129186 "Opponents scour Ben Sasse's old writings for fodder".] [http://www.omaha.com/ ''Omaha World-Herald''.] November 25, 2013. Retrieved 2014-01-13. The Osborn campaign cited, among other pieces, a 2009 ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'' column titled "Health-Care Reform: The Rush to Pass a Bad Bill", stating that "There's an emerging consensus that this [an individual mandate] might be a good idea",Sasse, Benjamin E. [http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2009-07-01/health-care-reform-the-rush-to-pass-a-bad-bill "Health-Care Reform: The Rush to Pass a Bad Bill"], businessweek.com; retrieved January 3, 2014. and a 2010 speech in which Sasse said Republicans would probably lack the votes to repeal the ACA, stating that "a middle-class entitlement has never been repealed", and opining that Republicans had failed to offer a viable alternative, preferring to stage "symbolic repeal votes".Zavadil, Chris. [http://m.fremonttribune.com/news/local/sasse-speaks-at-health-care-summit/article_adc24f82-e95c-11df-bef2-001cc4c03286.html?mobile_touch=true "Sasse speaks at health care summit"], remonttribune.com; retrieved November 15, 2013. Sasse's response to the Osborn campaign's assertions was that in his articles and speeches, he was describing the political landscape rather than giving his own opinions on the merits of the ACA's provisions; to a ''World-Herald'' reporter, he declared, "I have never changed my position on thinking Obamacare is a bad idea". On May 13, 2014, Sasse won 92 of 93 counties{{cite news|last1=Walton|first1=Don|title=Sasse is new Republican voice|url=http://journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/federal-politics/sasse-is-new-republican-voice/article_ceaa5774-d3c6-5a66-bab0-c0c95cc21645.html|newspaper=Lincoln Journal Star|accessdate=October 27, 2014|date=October 19, 2014}} and secured the Republican nomination with 109,829 votes, or 49.4% of all votes cast; banker Sid Dinsdale came in second, with 49,829 votes (22.4%), followed by Osborn, with 46,850 votes (21.1%).[http://elections.nytimes.com/2014/results/primaries/nebraska "Nebraska Primary Election Results".] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524030958/http://elections.nytimes.com/2014/results/primaries/nebraska |date=May 24, 2014 }} [https://www.nytimes.com/ ''New York Times''.] No date on story. Retrieved October 20, 2014. On November 4, 2014, Sasse won the general election for the U.S. Senate, defeating Democratic nominee [[David Domina]] with 64.4% of the vote to Domina's 31.5%.[http://www.sos.ne.gov/elec/2014/results/2014-General-Canvass-Recount-Final.pdf "Official Report of the Board of State Canvassers of the State of Nebraska: General Election, November 4, 2014."] [http://www.sos.ne.gov/dyindex.html Nebraska Secretary of State.] Retrieved January 8, 2015. [https://web.archive.org/web/20150108223535/http://www.sos.ne.gov/elec/2014/results/2014-General-Canvass-Recount-Final.pdf Archived 2015-01-08] at [https://archive.org/ Wayback Machine]. [[File:Ben Sasse by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|Sasse speaking at 2015 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]]]] ===Tenure=== Sasse assumed office as a United States senator on January 3, 2015. He was officially sworn in when the [[114th United States Congress|114th Congress]] convened on January 6, 2015. '''Committees''' Sasse has been appointed to serve on the following committees in the 115th Congress:[http://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/senate-republican-committee-assignments-for-the-115th-congress "Senate GOP Releases Committee Assignments for the 115th Congress"], senate.gov; retrieved January 10, 2017. * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Committee on Armed Services]]''' * '''[[United States Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs|Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs]]''' **[[United States Senate Banking Subcommittee on Economic Policy|Subcommittee on Economic Policy]] **[[United States Senate Banking Subcommittee on National Security and International Trade and Finance|Subcommittee on National Security and International Trade and Finance]] **[[United States Senate Banking Subcommittee on Securities, Insurance, and Investment|Subcommittee on Securities, Insurance, and Investment]] * '''[[United States Congress Joint Economic Committee|Joint Economic Committee]]''' * '''[[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Committee on the Judiciary]]''' ==Political positions== === Abortion === Sasse's campaign website indicated that he was [[pro-life]], stating "even one abortion is too many".[https://web.archive.org/web/20140418022348/https://www.sassefornebraska.com/issues/defending-unborn "Defending the Unborn"], [https://www.sassefornebraska.com/ Sasse for Nebraska] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323031605/https://www.sassefornebraska.com/|date=March 23, 2014}}; archived from [https://www.sassefornebraska.com/issues/defending-unborn the original] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418022348/https://www.sassefornebraska.com/issues/defending-unborn|date=April 18, 2014}} === Donald Trump === In early 2016, during both parties' presidential primary election seasons, Sasse announced that he would not support Republican front-runner [[Donald Trump]] should Trump become the party's nominee; he was the first sitting senator to make such an announcement.Levy, Gabrielle. [https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-02-29/ben-sasse-vows-to-oppose-trump-in-november "Republicans Vow to Oppose Trump in November".] [https://www.usnews.com/ ''U.S. News & World Report''.] February 29, 2016. Retrieved March 4, 2016. Sasse questioned Trump's commitment to the [[United States Constitution|U.S. Constitution]], in particular accusing him of attacking the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]; stated that Trump had refused to condemn the [[Ku Klux Klan]]; and suggested that Trump "thinks he's running for King".Sasse, Ben. [https://www.facebook.com/sassefornebraska/posts/561073597391141 "An open letter to Trump supporters".] Facebook, February 28, 2016. Retrieved March 4, 2016. He stated that if Trump won the party's nomination, then he would vote neither for him nor for Democratic front-runner [[Hillary Clinton]], but would probably "look for some third candidate—a conservative option, a Constitutionalist". He did not say that he would leave the party if Trump was nominated.Morton, Joseph. [http://www.omaha.com/news/politics/ben-sasse-if-gop-embraces-politics-of-donald-trump-i/article_5fba53b6-e000-11e5-a19c-af6472f4a7e7.html "Ben Sasse: If GOP embraces politics of Donald Trump, 'I'm out{{'"}}.] [http://www.omaha.com/ ''Omaha World-Herald''.] March 2, 2016. Retrieved March 4, 2016. Trump, asked about Sasse's third-party suggestion, replied, "That would be the work of a loser." Several Nebraska Republican politicians, among them state senators [[Bob Krist]] and [[Beau McCoy]] and U.S. senator [[Deb Fischer]], took exception to Sasse's statements. Krist described them as "very immature" and declared that Sasse should "quietly and in a statesmanlike manner allow the system to work out and provide the leadership that needs to be provided"; Fischer said that voting for a third-party alternative would essentially guarantee a Clinton victory.Daly, Matthew. [https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2016-03-04/tangling-with-trump-freshman-nebraska-senator-relishes-it "Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse is again tangling with Donald Trump and his supporters".] [https://www.usnews.com/ ''U.S. News & World Report''.] March 4, 2016. Retrieved March 4, 2016. Two-page article; Krist's comments are on first page, Fischer's on second. Sasse has described Trump as a "'megalomaniac strongman,'" has "called the president’s tariffs on steel and aluminum imports 'dumb,' and has described Trump’s escalating trade war with China [as] 'nuts.'"{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/09/sasse-trump-republican-senate-never-702071|title=Sasse tempts Trump’s wrath by refusing to bow|work=Politico|last=Isenstadt|first=Alex|date=July 9, 2018|access-date=September 29, 2018}} In March 2018, Sasse criticized Trump for congratulating Vladimir Putin on his election win,{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/03/21/sasse-trump-putin-russia-479045|title=Sasse rips Trump for congratulating Putin on 'sham' election win|work=POLITICO|access-date=2018-03-23}} saying, "The president of the United States was wrong to congratulate him, and the White House press secretary was wrong to duck a simple question about whether or not Putin's reelection was free and fair. It was not. The American people know that, the Russian people know that and the world knows that. The White House refused to speak directly and clearly about this matter; we were weakened as a nation and a tyrant was strengthened." In July 2018, ''[[Politico]]'' reported that Sasse had "quietly launched a new political non-profit group, fueling speculation that he might launch a Hail Mary bid for president rather than seek another term in the Senate." However, ''Politico'' also reported that Sasse and the President have been talking multiple times each month.{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/09/sasse-trump-republican-senate-never-702071|title=Sasse tempts Trump’s wrath by refusing to bow|work=Politico|last=Isenstadt|first=Alex|date=July 9, 2018|access-date=September 29, 2018}} Sasse has not ruled out a 2020 presidential bid.{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/09/09/sasse-republicans-senate-nebraska-812844|title=Sasse: ‘Every morning’ I consider leaving the GOP |work=Politico|last=O'Brien|first=Connor|date=September 9, 2018|access-date=September 29, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nfl/sasse-wont-rule-out-2020-presidential-run/vp-BBN5lDE|title=Sasse won't rule out 2020 presidential run|work=CNN|date=September 9, 2018|access-date=September 29, 2018}} === Guns === In Sasse's Senate run in 2014, he received an "AQ" rating from the [[National Rifle Association]] (NRA). According to the NRA's press release, the rating was the most favorable that could be given to a candidate who had no voting record on gun-related issues. The NRA endorsed Sasse in the race.{{cite web|title=NRA Endorses Ben Sasse for U.S. Senate in Nebraska|url=https://www.nrapvf.org/articles/20140908/nra-endorses-ben-sasse-for-us-senate-in-nebraska|website=NRA-PVF|accessdate=October 5, 2017|language=en}} === Health care === In announcing his Senate candidacy, Sasse expressed strong opposition to the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] (ACA, a.k.a. "Obamacare"), describing himself as "the anti-Obamacare candidate"{{cite news|url=http://journalstar.com/ben-sasse-i-m-running-to-repeal-the-obamacare-worldview/article_0b15125a-1ed0-55b2-a1b1-50224ecea5f0.html|title=Ben Sasse: I'm running to repeal the Obamacare worldview|author=Ben Sasse|date=December 3, 2013|newspaper=Lincoln Journal Star|accessdate=October 7, 2013}} and later declaring that "[i]f it lives, America as we know it will die." In the Senate, Sasse continued to support repeal of the ACA. In 2017, with Republicans unable to develop a repeal-and-replace plan that could secure a majority in the Senate, Sasse proposed an immediate repeal with a one-year delay in implementation, and called on the Senate to give up its August recess to allow it to work on a replacement measure.Morton, Joseph. [http://www.omaha.com/livewellnebraska/ben-sasse-offers-alternative-strategy-amid-uncertainty-over-gop-health/article_a30c72c6-5d85-11e7-af32-5b3d2cb3d4fa.html "Ben Sasse offers alternative strategy amid uncertainty over GOP health care bill".] [http://www.omaha.com/ ''Omaha World-Herald''.] July 1, 2017. Retrieved October 5, 2017. In 2016, Sasse was the only senator from either party to vote against the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act, which was intended to address abuse of heroin and opioid drugs by providing funds to the states for treatment and prevention programs and by making the anti-overdose drug [[naloxone]] more widely available to first responders and law enforcement agencies. Sasse said he was "distressed by opioid abuse" but questioned whether drug treatment should be addressed at the federal level.{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2016/03/10/senate_passes_bill_addressing_heroin_opioid_crisis_129935.html|title=Senate Passes Bill Addressing Heroin, Opioid Crisis|last1=Arkin|first1=James|date=March 10, 2016|publisher=Real Clear Politics|accessdate=March 12, 2016}} === LGBT issues === in 2014, Sasse's campaign website did not refer explicitly to same-sex marriage, but stated, "Ben believes marriage is between one man & one woman".[https://sassefornebraska.com/ "Issues": Sasse for Nebraska] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017224100/https://www.sassefornebraska.com/ |date=October 17, 2014 }}; retrieved October 19, 2014. [https://web.archive.org/web/20141017230835/https://www.sassefornebraska.com/issues archived October 17, 2014 at archive.org] === Spending === In September 2018, Sasse, five other Republican senators ([[Jeff Flake]], [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]], [[Rand Paul]], [[David Perdue]], and [[Pat Toomey]]), and [[Bernie Sanders]] voted against a $854 billion spending bill meant to avoid a government shutdown. The bill included funding for the Departments of Defense, Health and Human Services, Labor and Education.{{cite web |last1=CARNEY |first1=JORDAIN |last2=ELIS |first2=NIV |title=Senate approves $854B spending bill |url=https://thehill.com/policy/finance/407218-senate-approves-854b-spending-bill |website=The Hill |accessdate=19 September 2018}} ==Books== Sasse is the author of ''[[The Vanishing American Adult]]'' (2017){{cite news|last1=Morton|first1=Joseph|title=Ben Sasse's 'The Vanishing American Adult' isn't your typical lawmaker's book|url=http://www.omaha.com/news/nebraska/ben-sasse-s-the-vanishing-american-adult-isn-t-your/article_25e27bdf-c13b-5ebe-992b-d4225657be54.html|accessdate=May 10, 2017|publisher=Omaha World-Herald|date=May 9, 2017}} and ''Them: Why We Hate Each Other - and How to Heal'' (2018) {{ASIN|B07BN4W5GY}} Sasse also co-edited the book ''Here We Stand!: A Call from Confessing Evangelicals for a Modern Reformation'' with theologian [[James Montgomery Boice]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Here-Stand-Confessing-Evangelicals-Reformation/dp/0875526705|title=Here We Stand!: A Call From Confessing Evangelicals For A Modern Reformation|last=results|first=search|last2=Sasse|first2=Benjamin E.|date=2004-09-03|publisher=P & R Publishing|isbn=9780875526706|location=Phillipsburg, N.J.|language=English}} ==Personal life== Sasse and his wife, Melissa (née McLeod) Sasse, live in [[Fremont, Nebraska]], with their three children. The children are [[Homeschooling|homeschooled]].[http://sarpycountygop.com/voter-tools/candidate-list/ben-sasse-bio/ "Ben Sasse Bio"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216221804/http://sarpycountygop.com/voter-tools/candidate-list/ben-sasse-bio|date=December 16, 2014}} [http://sarpycountygop.com/ Sarpy County Republican Party]; retrieved December 16, 2014 and archived. [https://web.archive.org/web/20141216221804/http://sarpycountygop.com/voter-tools/candidate-list/ben-sasse-bio on December 16, 2014 at] [https://archive.org/web Wayback Machine]{{cite web|title=Ben Sasse Biography|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/150182/ben-sasse#.Vt9ua2z2ZPY|publisher=''[[Project Vote Smart]]''|accessdate=March 8, 2016}} Sasse was raised a [[Lutheran]] and baptized in the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]]. As an undergraduate in the early 1990s, he encountered the teachings of [[Robert Godfrey|W. Robert Godfrey]] at the Bolton Conference. Sasse identifies this as the time when he and his wife first began to embrace the "reformed faith".{{Cite web|url=https://www.wscal.edu/resource-center/commencement-address-2016|title=2016 Commencement Address: Never Again Will Jerusalem Grieve.|last=Sasse|first=Ben|date=June 9, 2016|website=Westminster Seminary California|at=2:00 minute mark|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} He later became an [[presbyter|elder]] in the [[United Reformed Churches in North America]] and served on the board of trustees for [[Westminster Seminary California]].[https://wscal.edu/media/docs/Academics_Catalogue.pdf Westminster Seminary California, Catalogue 2014–2015], p. 89; retrieved June 27, 2016. He is a member of Grace Church, a [[Presbyterian Church in America]] (PCA) congregation, in Fremont.Derrick, J. C. [https://world.wng.org/2016/09/ben_sasse_a_reformed_reformer "Ben Sasse: A Reformed reformer"], world.wng.org; retrieved October 5, 2016. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [https://www.sasse.senate.gov U.S. Senator Ben Sasse] official U.S. Senate site * {{Dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Nebraska/Government/Federal/US_Senate/Ben_Sasse_%5BR%5D/}} * {{C-SPAN|benjaminsasse}} * {{CongLinks | congbio = S001197 | fec=S4NE00090 | congress=ben-sasse/S001197 | votesmart=150182 }} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=Michael O'Grady}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|[[Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Planning and Evaluation]]}}|years=2007–2009}} {{s-aft|after=Sherry Glied}} |- {{s-aca}} {{s-bef|before=Stephen Fritz}} {{s-ttl|title=President of [[Midland University]]|years=2010–2014}} {{s-aft|after=Jody Horner}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mike Johanns]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for [[List of United States Senators from Nebraska|U.S. Senator]] from [[Nebraska]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Bernard Buffet | image = Bernard Buffet crop.jpg | caption = Bernard Buffet in front of his studio in Tourtour | birth_name = Bernard Buffet | birth_date = {{Birth date|1928|7|10|df=y}} | birth_place = Paris, France | death_date = {{Death date and age|1999|10|4|1928|7|10|df=y}} | death_place = [[Tourtour]], France | nationality = French | field = [[Painting]], [[Drawing]], [[Printmaking]] | training = [[École Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-Arts]] | movement = [[Expressionism]] | works = | patrons = | awards = Member of the [[Salon d'Automne]], 1947
Member of the [[Société des Artistes Indépendants]], 1947
''Prix de la Critique'', 1948
''Prix Puvis de Chavannes'', 1950
Officer of the [[Légion d'Honneur]],1973
Member of the [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]], 1974 }} '''Bernard Buffet''' ({{IPA-fr|byfɛ|lang}}; 10 July 1928 – 4 October 1999) was a French painter of [[Expressionism]] and a member of the anti-abstract art group ''L'homme Témoin'' (the Witness-Man)."DuMont's Künstlerlexikon", ''DuMont Buchverlag Köln'', [[Cologne]], 1997 ==Life and work== Buffet was born in Paris, France, and studied art there at the [[École Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-Arts]] (National School of the Fine Arts) and worked in the studio of the painter [[Eugène Narbonne]]. Among his classmates were [[Maurice Boitel]] and [[Louis Vuillermoz]]. Sustained by the picture-dealer [[Maurice Garnier]], Buffet produced religious pieces, landscapes, portraits and [[still-life]]s. In 1946, he had his first painting shown, a self-portrait, at the Salon des Moins de Trente Ans at the Galerie Beaux-Arts. He had at least one major exhibition every year. Buffet illustrated "Les Chants de Maldoror" written by [[Comte de Lautréamont]] in 1952. In 1955, he was awarded the first prize by the magazine Connaissance des Arts, which named the ten best post-war artists. In 1958, at the age of 30, the first retrospective of his work was held at the Galerie Charpentier. [[Pierre Bergé]] was Buffet's live-in lover until Bergé[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/bernard-buffet-return-of-the-poser-1645748.html Bernard Buffet: Return of the 'poser' – Features – Art]. The Independent (16 March 2009). Retrieved on 26 July 2014. left Buffet for [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]]. On 12 December 1958, Buffet married the writer and [[actress]] Annabel Schwob. They adopted three children.http://www.parismatch.com/Culture/Livres/franoise-sagan-nicolas-buffet-alcool-143654 Daughter Virginie was born in 1962, daughter Danielle in 1963 and son Nicolas was born in 1973. Bernard Buffet was named "Chevalier de la [[Legion of Honour|Légion d'Honneur]]" in 1973. On 23 November 1973, the Bernard Buffet Museum was founded by Kiichiro Okano, in Surugadaira, Japan. At the request of the French postal administration in 1978, he designed a stamp depicting the Institut et le Pont des Arts – on this occasion the Post Museum arranged a retrospective of his works.MMK Museum für Moderne Kunst, [[Frankfurt|Frankfurt am Main]], "Bernard Buffet Maler Painter Peintre", ''Brochure'', 2008, April Buffet created more than 8,000 paintings and many [[Printmaking|prints]] as well. Buffet committed [[suicide]]{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/bernard-buffet-return-of-the-poser-1645748.html|title=Bernard Buffet: Return of the 'poser'|publisher=The Independent|date=16 March 2009|accessdate=28 August 2009}} at his home in [[Tourtour]], southern France, on 4 October 1999. He was suffering from [[Parkinson's disease]] and was no longer able to work. Police said that Buffet died around 4 p.m after putting his head in a plastic bag attached around his neck with tape. The popularity of Buffet's work, as well as the level of media attention around his lifestyle, were quite high in the 1950s and 1960s. Although he kept on painting throughout his life, there was a certain decline in interest with is work in the later decades of the 20th century. Especially so in his native country. This decline in popularity was partly influenced by his fall from grace with French art pundits, whose support and interest shifted away from figurative art. In the 21st century there has been a renewed spike in interest in the work of Bernard Buffet. With some successful exhibitions in France and throughout the world. In 2016, British author Nicholas Foulkes published [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Bernard-Buffet-Invention-Modern-Mega-artist/dp/1848094442 ''Bernard Buffet: The Invention of the Modern Mega-Artist']', in which he offers a controversial biographical account of Buffet's life and work. In recent years, his children, as well as grandchildren, UK resident Timothé (b. 1995), Taïmour (b. 2000), Manon and Manolo, have been actively working towards promoting the work of Bernard Buffet.
