revision.text:
{{short description|Political Consultant}} {{Infobox person |name = Jeff Roe |birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date|43|2016|1|20}}[https://newrepublic.com/article/127717/ted-cruzs-howitzer Ted Cruz’s Howitzer] |birth_place = [[Brookfield, Missouri|Brookfield]], [[Missouri]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |alma_mater = [[Northwest Missouri State University|Northwest Missouri State
University]] |website = {{url|axiomstrategies.com|Official website}} }} '''Jeff Roe''' (born 1972/73) is an American [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] political consultant and strategist.{{cite news|last1=Mannies|first1=Jo|last2=McDaniel|first2=Chris|last3=Rosenbaum|first3=Jason|title=Politically Speaking: Jeff Roe Recounts Best Ways To Sell Campaign, Predicts GOP Success This Fall|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/politically-speaking-jeff-roe-recounts-best-ways-sell-campaign-predicts-gop-success-fall|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=St. Louis Public Radio|date=June 17, 2014}} He is the founder and principal of Axiom Strategies, a political consulting firm located in [[Kansas City, Missouri]], with offices in [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[Dallas, Texas]]. He formerly served as [[Chief of Staff]], campaign manager, and longtime aide for [[United States Congress|U.S. Representative]] [[Sam Graves]].{{cite web|title=Our Principal|url=http://www.axiomstrategies.com/Groups/1000081108/Axiom_Strategies/Experience_and_Results/Meet_Our_Principal/Meet_Our_Principal.aspx|publisher=Axiom Strategies|accessdate=13 March 2015}} Known for his aggressive campaign techniques, Roe has earned a reputation as a "bare-knuckle" political operative who "plays to win."{{cite news|last1=Drebes|first1=Dave|title=Will Missouri's primary splinter GOP's board of directors?|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/stories/2008/02/04/editorial4.html?page=2|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=St. Louis Business Journal|date=February 3, 2008}}{{cite news|last1=Kraske |first1=Steve |title=Jeff Roe evolves into a mainstream player |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/11/29/3293031/jeff-roe-evolves-into-a-mainstream.html |accessdate=13 March 2015 |publisher=Kansas City Star |date=November 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202224020/http://www.kansascity.com/2011/11/29/3293031/jeff-roe-evolves-into-a-mainstream.html |archivedate=December 2, 2011 }}{{cite news|title=GOP hopefuls off and running in Missouri's '08 AG race |url=http://www.legalnewsline.com/news/190488-gop-hopefuls-off-and-running-in-missouris-08-ag-race |accessdate=13 March 2015 |publisher=Legal Newsline Legal Journal |date=February 13, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023101036/http://www.legalnewsline.com/news/190488-gop-hopefuls-off-and-running-in-missouris-08-ag-race |archivedate=October 23, 2007 }} Roe has been called "the next [[Karl Rove]]". His political consulting firm, Axiom Strategies, has won over 50 "Pollie" & Reed awards on its way to an "81% win rate".{{cite news|last1=Zimpfer|first1=Travis|title=Jeff Roe leads Cruz campaign to Iowa caucus victory|url=http://themissouritimes.com/26722/jeff-roe-leads-cruz-campaign-to-iowa-caucus-victory/|accessdate=4 March 2016|publisher=Missouri Times|date=February 2, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Faughn|first1=Scott|title=Axiom Strategies direct mail earns 20 Pollie Awards|url=http://themissouritimes.com/2654/axiom-strategies-direct-mail-earns-20-pollie-awards/|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Missouri Times|date=April 27, 2013}} Roe has consulted for a variety of local, state, and federal political campaigns. Notable clients have included [[Mike Huckabee]], [[Rick Perry]] and [[Ted Cruz]]. Roe was the senior strategist and campaign manager for [[Ted Cruz presidential campaign, 2016|Cruz's 2016 presidential bid]].{{cite news|last1=Zezima|first1=Katie|title=Meet the people who will help Ted Cruz try to get to the White House|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/03/23/meet-the-people-who-will-help-ted-cruz-try-to-get-to-the-white-house/|accessdate=23 March 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=March 23, 2015}} ==Background== Roe is a native of [[Brookfield, Missouri]]. He grew up on his family's corn, soybean, and hog farm. Roe helped raise pigs and cattle on his family's farm. When asked how his upbringing prepared him for a career in politics, Roe said "hog farms are a lot cleaner." His family did not have strong political leanings, and his childhood dream was to become a [[Major League Baseball]] umpire.{{cite news|last1=Vockrodt|first1=Steve|title=Political consultant Roe cultivates conservative campaigns|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/stories/2008/04/14/story10.html|accessdate=5 February 2016|publisher=Kansas City Business Journal|date=April 13, 2008}} Roe became an [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]] before joining the [[Army National Guard]] at age 17. He served in a 155 mm Howitzer Unit in South Korea, leaving the military in 1994. He graduated from [[Northwest Missouri State University]] in 1994.{{cite news|title=Northwest Alumni Magazine|url=https://www.nwmissouri.edu/alumni/PDF/magazine/2007_spring.pdf|accessdate=4 March 2016|publisher=Northwest Alumni Magazine|date=Spring 2007}} He wrote conservative pieces for his college's newspaper. He currently lives with his wife and daughter in [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. Roe is known for chewing [[Red Man]] Golden Blend chewing tobacco. ==Political career== Roe's political career began in 1994, working for then-Missouri State Representative [[Sam Graves]]. Following Graves' election to the [[Missouri State Senate]] in 1994 and then the [[United States Congress]] in 2000, Roe became Graves' Chief of Staff. In 2005, Roe left his position with Graves and founded Axiom Strategies, a Republican campaign consulting firm based in Kansas City, Missouri. By 2008, Axiom Strategies had grown into a multimillion-dollar-a-year company. In addition to Axiom Strategies, Roe founded creative agency and direct mail firm Candidate Command and polling and public opinion research company Remington Research Group.{{cite news|last1=Helling|first1=Dave|title=Streetcar leads in poll, but campaign too close to call|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article820654.html|accessdate=24 March 2015|publisher=Kansas City Star|date=July 28, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Ruess|first1=Brittany|title=Axiom Strategies establishes new direct voter contact firm|url=http://themissouritimes.com/6112/axiom-strategies-establishes-new-direct-voter-contact-firm/|accessdate=24 March 2015|publisher=Missouri Times|date=August 14, 2013}} Roe restructured his business model in August 2013 in order to handle an uptick in business. Axiom's internal direct mail capability was spun off into a standalone business called Candidate Command, and both the mail firm and Axiom grew by 40%. Roe also owns Capitol Franking Group, which creates franked mail for members of Congress. After successfully managing several elections throughout the Midwest, including helping the Republican Party take over Missouri's General Assembly for the first time in 50 years, Roe expanded Axiom Strategies' operations to a national level in 2008, opening a second office in [[Washington, D.C.]] and working for Governor [[Mike Huckabee]]'s presidential campaign in 2008, as well as managing the successful election efforts of several Missouri Congressmen.{{cite news|last1=Drucker|first1=David|title=Ted Cruz builds team for 2016|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/ted-cruz-builds-team-for-2016/article/2552574|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Washington Examiner|date=August 28, 2014}} In 2006, Congressman Sam Graves' brother [[Todd Graves (attorney)|Todd Graves]] was wrongfully dismissed from his position as a U.S. Attorney. It was discovered that Todd Graves' firing was retaliation from [[Kit Bond|Senator Kit Bond]]'s office over Sam Graves' refusal to fire Roe.{{cite news|last1=Kravitz|first1=Derek|title=How a Missouri Feud Ousted a U.S. Attorney|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/washingtonpostinvestigations/2008/10/report_missouri_attorney_fight.html|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=October 3, 2008}} Roe and his consulting firm widened their national footprint in 2010, contributing to the election efforts of Congressmen [[Allen West (politician)|Allen West]] (FL-22),{{cite news|last1=Kapur|first1=Sahil|title=Ted Cruz's Brain Trust: The Advisers Who Want To Make Him President|url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/dc/ted-cruz-top-advisers|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Talking Points Memo|date=November 20, 2014}} [[Rick Crawford (politician)|Rick Crawford]] (AR-1), [[Kevin Yoder]] (KS-3), [[Blaine Luetkemeyer]] (MO-9), [[Sam Graves]] (MO-6), [[Billy Long]] (MO-7), [[Chuck Fleischmann]] (TN-3), [[Jo Ann Emerson]] (MO-8) and Senators [[Roy Blunt]] (MO), [[Jerry Moran]] (KS) and [[John Boozman]] (AR). Roe also counted a number of high-profile losing clients the same year, including Wink Harman, [[Jim Barnett (Kansas politician)|Jim Barnett]], [[Bill Stouffer]], and [[Van Tran]]. In 2011, ''[[The Kansas City Star]]'' wrote that Roe had "evolved into a mainstream player," citing his work to pass a Kansas City [[Sales tax in the United States|sales tax]] increase to create a nicer home for wild animals at the [[Kansas City Zoo]]. Democratic campaign consultant Steve Glorioso said Roe's work on behalf of the zoo tax increase "raised Roe's stature with the civic community" and that Roe's opponents "probably discovered his horns have smooth, not sharp, edges." His staff grew from eight people in 2008 to seventeen by 2011. In the 2012 election cycle, Axiom Strategies worked for [[Rick Perry]]'s presidential campaign and for [[Richard Mourdock]] in his upset over [[Dick Lugar]] in the Indiana Senate primary. Roe also played a role in Christi Craddick's successful bid for Texas Railroad Commissioner and [[David Dewhurst]]'s unsuccessful United States Senate campaign. Following the 2012 election cycle, Axiom Strategies won 20 [[American Association of Political Consultants|Pollie]] awards, winning twice as many as their nearest competitor. Axiom was recognized for winning the most Pollies of any Republican mail firm in the United States. Other clients included the [[National Association of Realtors]], Congressman [[Richard Hudson (U.S. politician)|Richard Hudson]] (NC-8) and Congresswoman [[Ann Wagner]] (MO-2). For his role defeating Proposition B in Missouri, the closest ballot initiative in Missouri since 1992, Roe was named Missouri's "2012 General Consultant All Star."{{cite web|title=MoScout Readers 2012 All-Star Political Consultants|url=http://moscout.com/moscout-readers-2012-all-star-political-consultants/|publisher=Missouri Scout|accessdate=13 March 2015}} He was also named one of Missouri's top 5 GOP "Influencers" by ''[[Campaigns & Elections Magazine]]''. In 2013, Roe was chosen to speak at the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] (CPAC). Gregg Keller, at the time the executive director of the [[American Conservative Union]], said Roe was invited to speak at the event because he was "one of the most successful political consultants in the country." Roe said the speaking invitation validated a career path which he had launched by knocking on doors for political candidates.{{cite news|last1=Faughn|first1=Scott|title=Jeff Roe chosen to speak at CPAC|url=http://themissouritimes.com/1420/jeff-roe-chosen-to-speak-at-cpac/|accessdate=5 February 2016|publisher=The Missouri Times|date=March 4, 2013}} Roe was hired by [[Catherine Hanaway]] for her [[Missouri gubernatorial election, 2016|2016 gubernatorial campaign]] in Missouri.{{cite news|last1=Yokley|first1=Eli|title=While Schweich focuses on reelection, Hanaway gubernatorial campaign taking shape|url=http://politicmo.com/2014/02/02/while-schweich-focuses-on-reelection-hanaway-gubernatorial-campaign-taking-shape/|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=PoliticoMO|date=February 2, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Kraske|first1=Steve|title=Jeff Roe speaks out on anti-Tom Schweich radio ad, says he paid for it with his own money|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article18610395.html|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=The Kansas City Star|date=April 15, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Virginia|title=Citizens for Fairness was front group for Hanaway's consultant|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/citizens-for-fairness-was-front-group-for-hanaway-s-consultant/article_95c47660-7f3f-5e34-9071-7bfbbafacc60.html|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=March 15, 2015}} Roe's campaign tactics have been criticized by former U.S. Senator [[John Danforth]].{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Virginia|last2=McDermott|first2=Kevin|title=Danforth, in eulogy, decries 'whispering campaign' against Schweich|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/danforth-in-eulogy-decries-whispering-campaign-against-schweich/article_6d81a9c8-0d79-5a1e-9210-9515777afd0f.html|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=March 4, 2015}} Roe regularly provides commentary for news outlets and publications such as ''The Kansas City Star'', ''Washington Post'', ''Wall Street Journal'', ''Roll Call'', ''The Hill'', Fox News, ''Politico'' and radio stations such as [[KMBC-TV|KMBC]] and [[WPHT]].{{cite news|last1=Murray|first1=Shailagh|title=America's heartland sees little need for a political insurrection|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/07/03/AR2010070303110.html|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=July 4, 2010}}{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Tricia|title=Graves Rises to Top of Potential GOP Challengers to McCaskill, Poll Shows|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/-202911-1.html?zkMobileView=true|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Roll Call|date=January 27, 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Catanese|first1=David|title=The new GOP litmus test|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/davidcatanese/0611/The_new_GOP_litmus_test_.html?showall|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Politico|date=June 24, 2011}} ===2014 election cycle=== In 2014, Roe hired Travis Smith, the former chief-of-staff for Congressman [[Kevin Yoder]].{{cite news|title=Roe expanding consultancy hegemon|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article340464/Roe-expanding-consultancy-hegemon.html|accessdate=5 February 2016|publisher=Kansas City Star|date=February 26, 2014}} That same year, Roe was the lead consultant for [[Martha McSally]]'s successful bid for Congress, in which she defeated incumbent [[Ron Barber]] by 167 votes in the closest congressional election in Arizona history. McSally's victory was the closest congressional race in the nation for 2014.{{cite news|last1=Rojas|first1=Rick|title=Martha McSally, Republican Challenger, Wins in Arizona Midterm Race|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/18/us/martha-mcsally-a-republican-challenger-wins-recount-in-arizona-election.html|accessdate=14 April 2015|publisher=The New York Times|date=December 17, 2014}} Roe was also involved in [[Mark Walker (North Carolina politician)|Mark Walker]] and [[David Rouzer]]'s elections to open congressional seats in North Carolina and [[Glenn Grothman]]'s election to the open congressional seat in Wisconsin. He also consulted for the re-election bids of [[Kevin Yoder]], [[Ann Wagner]], [[Sam Graves]], [[Blaine Luetkemeyer]], [[Billy Long]], [[Chuck Fleischmann]] and [[Jason T. Smith|Jason Smith]]. Roe was part of the team in [[Bruce Rauner]]'s successful campaign for governor in Illinois, [[Greg Abbott]]'s successful campaign for governor in Texas, and [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]]'s successful Wisconsin gubernatorial bid.{{cite news|last1=Roe |first1=Jeff |title=2014 Election In The Books |url=http://www.axiomstrategies.com/Articles/1000138597/Axiom_Strategies/Blog/Current_Events/2014_Election_In.aspx |accessdate=5 February 2016 |publisher=Axiom Strategies |date=November 11, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205133550/http://www.axiomstrategies.com/Articles/1000138597/Axiom_Strategies/Blog/Current_Events/2014_Election_In.aspx |archivedate= 5 February 2016 |df= }} In Texas State Senate races, Roe consulted for [[Bob Hall (Texas politician)|Bob Hall]], who ousted 12-year incumbent [[Bob Deuell]], and for [[Don Huffines]], who unseated nearly 20-year incumbent [[John Carona]].{{cite news|last1=Repko|first1=Melissa|title=Update: State legislative candidate Morgan Meyer wins runoff; Chart Westcott concedes in Facebook post|url=http://trailblazersblog.dallasnews.com/2014/05/pricey-personal-republican-runoff-between-morgan-meyer-chart-westcott-comes-to-a-close.html/|accessdate=23 March 2015|publisher=Dallas Morning News|date=May 27, 2014}} Roe was involved in five of the top ten Republican takeover seats in the country.{{cite news|last1=Faughn|first1=Scott|title=Five questions with: Jeff Roe|url=http://themissouritimes.com/8399/five-questions-jeff-roe/|accessdate=5 February 2016|publisher=The Missouri Times|date=February 21, 2014}} ===Ted Cruz 2016 presidential campaign=== {{main|Ted Cruz presidential campaign, 2016}} In 2014, Roe was hired by [[Ted Cruz]] as a political strategist. According to ''[[Politico]]'', Roe was brought on board to build out Cruz's political organization.{{cite news|last1=Everett|first1=Burgess|last2=Bresnahan|first2=John|title=Ted Cruz feeds 2016 buzz with hires|url= http://www.politico.com/story/2014/08/2016-elections-ted-cruz-110437.html|accessdate=13 March 2015|publisher=Politico|date=August 28, 2014}} After Cruz announced [[Ted Cruz presidential campaign, 2016|his candidacy for president]] on March 23, 2015, it was reported that Roe was the campaign manager and senior strategist for Cruz.{{cite news|last1=Hohmann|first1=James|last2=Isenstadt|first2=Alex|title=Cruz's strategy: Destroy the 'mushy middle'|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/cruzs-strategy-destroy-the-mushy-middle-116326.html|accessdate=24 March 2015|publisher=Politico|date=March 23, 2015}} In December 2015, ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' named Cruz's campaign "best of the 2016 campaign in 2015."{{cite news|last1=Catanese|first1=David|title=The Best and Worst of 2016 in 2015|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/run-2016/articles/2015-12-31/cruz-walker-biden-carson-the-best-and-worst-of-the-2016-white-house-race-so-far|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=U.S. News & World Report|date=December 31, 2015}} Roe is well known for using [[Microtargeting|sophisticated polling and campaign data]] to make strategic decisions, including targeting phone calls and other campaign messages to hit the ideas most likely to resonate with particular voters.{{cite news|last1=Canon|first1=Scott|title=KC's Jeff Roe featured as 'ruthless' but teary Cruz campaign chief on Fox|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/government-politics/article56351455.html|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=Kansas City Star|date=January 24, 2016}} Political columnist [[Al Hunt]] said that if Cruz is successful, "Roe may become a rock star in politics, on a par with [[Lee Atwater]], [[James Carville]], and [[David Plouffe]]."{{cite news|last1=Helling|first1=Dave|title=Jeff Roe a potential 'rock star,' veteran reporter says|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article57393218.html|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=Kansas City Star|date=January 29, 2016}} ''[[The New Republic]]'' called the Cruz campaign "a vintage Jeff Roe campaign: obsessively disciplined, well-funded, laser-focused on the base" and described Roe as "equal parts drill sergeant, data junkie, brawler, and entrepreneur."{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Andy|title=Ted Cruz's Howitzer|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/127717/ted-cruzs-howitzer|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=The New Republic|date=January 20, 2016}} On January 24, 2016, Roe was featured on ''[[Fox News Sunday]]'' with [[Chris Wallace]] as "Power Player of the Week". At the opening of his interview, Roe said "I think the rigors of democracy require us to have a real full-throated conversation about our beliefs, defend our beliefs, and point out the differences in our opponent's beliefs." {{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Chris|title=The man behind the secret to Ted Cruz's ground game|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/4719862950001/the-man-behind-the-secret-to-ted-cruzs-ground-game/?fb_ref=Default#sp=show-clips|accessdate=5 February 2016|publisher=Fox News|date=January 24, 2016}} Ted Cruz's victory in the 2016 Republican [[Iowa caucuses|Iowa caucus]] put Roe into the spotlight.{{cite news|last1=McDermott|first1=Kevin|title='Ruthless' Jeff Roe, veteran of rough Missouri politics, in spotlight after Cruz win|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/ruthless-jeff-roe-veteran-of-rough-missouri-politics-in-spotlight/article_c92f8e03-06e8-5415-a055-b98dac27a8ca.html|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=St. Louis Post Dispatch|date=February 3, 2016}} Roe was credited as "the architect of Cruz's first-place finish."{{cite news|last1=Fense|first1=Sarah|title=Missouri's Own Jeff Roe Was the Wind Beneath Ted Cruz's Iowa Wings|url=http://www.riverfronttimes.com/newsblog/2016/02/02/missouris-own-jeff-roe-was-the-wind-beneath-ted-cruzs-iowa-wings|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=Riverfront Times|date=February 2, 2016}} [[MSNBC]] commentator [[Willie Geist]] called Roe "the [[David Axelrod (political consultant)|David Axelrod]] of Cruz's campaign". Commenting on Roe's prediction that Cruz would win and [[Marco Rubio]] would come close to challenging [[Donald Trump]], Geist said: "They knew to the decimal point what their model could handle and that was almost exactly what the results were." ''[[National Review]]'' wrote that Roe was instrumental in the launch of Cruz's presidential campaign that defined him as the evangelical choice in the 2016 presidential election cycle, branding Cruz as "a divinely inspired warrior fighting a two-front battle against cultural secularism and big government."{{cite news|last1=Alberta|first1=Tim|last2=Johnson|first2=Eliana|title=Ted Cruz's Long Road to Iowa Victory|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/430666/ted-cruz-iowa-win-inside-story|accessdate=5 February 2016|publisher=National Review|date=February 2, 2016}} Cruz conceded defeat in the presidential race after the [[Indiana_Republican_primary,_2016|Indiana primary]]. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.axiomstrategies.com}} * [http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/fox-news-sunday-chris-wallace/videos#p/158303/v/4719862950001 Jeff Roe's "Power Player of the Week" segment on ''Fox News Sunday''] * [http://www.kansascity.com/news/government-politics/article53710895.html Campaign manager for soaring Ted Cruz moves from Kansas City to national stage] {{DEFAULTSORT:Roe, Jeff}} [[Category:American campaign managers]] [[Category:American political consultants]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Missouri Republicans]] [[Category:Northwest Missouri State University alumni]] [[Category:People associated with the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:Ted Cruz]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:1970s births]] [[Category:People from Brookfield, Missouri]]

{{Infobox military person | name = Khiuaz Dospanova | native_name = Хиуаз Доспанова | image = Khiuaz Dospanova in uniform.jpg | birth_date = 15 May 1922 | birth_place = [[Ganyushkino]], [[Atyrau Region]], [[Turkestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkestan ASSR]] | death_date = 20 May 2008 (aged 86) | death_place = [[Almaty]], [[Kazakhstan]] | allegiance = {{USSR}} | branch = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Soviet Air Force.svg}} [[Soviet Air Forces|Soviet Air Force]] | spouse = Shaku Amirov | rank = [[Senior lieutenant]] | serviceyears = 1942–1945 | unit = [[Night Witches|588th Night Bomber Regiment]] | battles = [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front of World War II]] | awards = [[Hero of Kazakhstan]] }} '''Khiuaz Kairovna Dospanova''' (Cyrillic: ''Хиуаз Каировна Доспанова''; 15 May 1922 – 20 May 2008) was a [[Kazakhs|Kazakh]] pilot who served in [[World War II]] in the [[Night Witches|588th Night Bomber Regiment]], nicknamed the "Night Witches." She was the only Kazakh woman to serve in the "Night Witches" and, although she was not awarded the title [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] unlike many of her Russian and Ukrainian colleagues, she was awarded the title [[Hero of Kazakhstan]] in 2004 for her service after independence.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.peoples.ru/military/aviation/hiyaz_dospanova/|title=Хиуаз Доспанова - Hiyaz Dospanova|last=|first=|date=|website=www.peoples.ru|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Early life == Born in [[Atyrau Region|Atyrau]], present-day [[Kazakhstan]], from her early childhood she dreamed of becoming a pilot. After completing secondary school she became certified as a reserve pilot. When World War II started she applied to the [[Military academies in Russia#Zhukovsky Air Force Academy|Zhukovsky Air Force Academy]] in Moscow, but her application was denied because the academy was for males only; she entered a medical institute instead in 1941.<ref name=":0" />
== Military career == When she heard of the recently formed all-female aviation regiments commanded by [[Marina Raskova]], she applied to the aviation college in Saratov. In 1942 she was placed in the [[Night Witches|588th Night Bomber Regiment]] under the command of experienced pilot [[Yevdokia Bershanskaya]], where Dospanova gained 300 flight hours in combat as a navigator and gunner, eventually reaching the rank of Senior Lieutenant .<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bestwriter.ru/fotoar.htm|title=Из архива Р. Ароновой|website=www.bestwriter.ru|access-date=2018-01-21}}</ref>
While landing after a mission in 1943, the [[Polikarpov Po-2]] Dospanova and pilot Julia Paskova were flying collided with another Po-2. Both pilots in the other plane were killed in the crash and Paskova died during surgery; Dospanova was assumed to be dead after not moving for a while, but nurses eventually realized she was still alive because she was not showing signs of [[pallor mortis]] long after they assumed her to be dead, so she underwent a series of surgeries over several days. Her legs developed [[gangrene]], but one doctor refused to amputate her legs, saying that she would need them. Dospanova had to wear casts on both of her legs for weeks and walked with a cane quite a while after the casts were removed. She returned to the regiment, but often required assistance of getting in and out the aircraft, and eventually became the regiment's head of communications after the previous head of communication, [[Valentina Stupina]], died.<ref name=":3" />
== Recognition == She was awarded various medals including the [[Order of the Red Star]], [[Order of the Patriotic War|Orders of the Patriotic War]] in 1st and 2nd class, and the title [[Hero of Kazakhstan]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://e-history.kz/en/publications/view/1095|title=Khiuaz Dospanova. The brave pilot · Publications · "Kazakhstan History" portal|website=e-history.kz|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kazakhworld.com/famous-female-kazakh-pilot-muse-atyrau-international-airports-new-name/#prettyPhoto|title=Famous Female Kazakh Pilot is the Muse for Atyrau International Airport’s New Name|last=Polascak|first=Marissa|date=|website=kazakhworld.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> There is an ice rink named after her, as well as a school and an [[Embraer E-Jet family|Embraer 190]] of [[Air Astana]]; [[Atyrau Airport|Atyrau International Airport]] is to be renamed in her honor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.tengrinews.kz/people/Atyrau-International-Airport-to-be-named-after-legendary-260269/|title=Atyrau International Airport to be named after legendary Kazakh female war pilot Dospanova|website=Tengrinews.kz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Aviation|Soviet Union}} * [[List of female Heroes of the Soviet Union]] * [[Zuleykha Seyidmammadova]] * [[Aliya Moldagulova]] * [[Manshuk Mametova]] * [[Alexey Maresyev]] * [[Douglas Bader]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dospanova, Khiuaz}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:Female aviators]] [[Category:Flight navigators]] [[Category:Ethnic Kazakh people]] [[Category:Women air force personnel of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Patriotic War, 2nd class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Patriotic War, 1st class]] [[Category:Soviet women in World War II]] [[Category:Heroes of Kazakhstan]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{notability|biographies|date=November 2008}} {{more footnotes|date=November 2008}} }}
{{Infobox person | name = Kim Miller | image = Kim_m.gif | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1988}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = [[Artist]] | nationality = }}__NOTOC__
'''Kim Miller''' (born 1988) is an American artist who was diagnosed with "classic" [[autism]] in 1991.{{citation needed|date=May 2009}} She began creating artwork at the age of 3 1/2 years old before she could functionally speak. At first, her artwork was just the outward articulation of an aloof, introverted, seemingly expressionless autistic child.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thegirlwhospokewithpictures.com/news/news6.jpg |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-01-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103164915/http://thegirlwhospokewithpictures.com/news/news6.jpg |archive-date=2013-11-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> After several years of utilizing sign language, delayed [[echolalia]] (the echoing of words and phrases), coupled with speech therapy, she learned to speak verbally as detailed in the book ''The Girl Who Spoke With Pictures'', which describes her advancement as a person with autism. Although Miller learned how to verbalize, she found it frustrating, difficult and time-consuming to communicate with words in real time. Drawing became a short cut to show her thoughts, feelings and needs.
Miller is often referred to as an "outside artist," [[outsider art]] self-taught and self-motivated.<ref>http://www.forewordreviews.com/reviews/the-girl-who-spoke-with-pictures/</ref> She is prolific in various mediums; acrylic paint, sculpting, ceramics, pencil as well as pen and ink. She is able to paint in a variety of styles exploring techniques such as [[pointillism]], [[German Expressionism]], or her own three-dimensional style; shifting from one painting to another as though simply changing fonts on the computer. Although some of the symptoms of autism (relating to objects rather than people, the fear of looking people in their faces, the inability to understand/process emotions) pose challenges, her unique work is outstanding for the fact that she chooses these very issues to examine and explore the complex human experience and relationships through her art.
== Awards and accomplishments == * Artwork selected for Autism Society of Oregon Calendar 2005 * Artwork selected for design for T-shirt to Autism Society of Oregon’s annual Portland Walkathon 2005 * Artwork juried and selected for DIVA Autism Artism Show 2006, 2007,2008 * Individual Division Award in Fine Arts (excellence in academics) 2006 * Confederation of Oregon School Administration Award (COSA) in Fine Arts 2006 * Presidential Education Award (3.75 GPA and above) 2006 * Scholarship of Merit from Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians * Exhaling Beauty- Art Show 2010
== Publications == Miller's work is featured in the following publications: * ''Autism Handbook for Parents: Facts and Strategies for Parenting Success'' by Janice E. Janzen (Kim Miller was 9 years old when this was published) Prufrock Press (March 1, 2009) * ''The Girl Who Spoke with Pictures: Autism Through Art'' by Eileen Miller and Kim Miller, (Sept. 2008) Jessica Kingsley Publishing * ''Autism, A Guide for Educators, Clinicians and Parents'' (Jan 13, 2008) by G. Robert Buckendorf, Ph.D., and CCC-SLP, Super Duper Publications (January 13, 2008) * ''Apples for Cheyenne'' by Elizabeth Gerlach, Illustrator- Kim Miller (2010) Future Horizons
Publications regarding Miller: * ''Behind the Pictures: Autism, Strategies for Change'' by Eileen Miller, Sept. 2010 Mimic Queen Publications
== References == {{reflist}} * Williams, Emily L. Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders. Volume 39, Number 10, 1493-1494, {{doi|10.1007/s10803-009-0770-z}} * Wright, J. (2010), The Girl Who Spoke with Pictures: Autism through Art. International Journal of Language & Communication Disorders, 45: 130. {{doi|10.3109/13682820902733368}} * Spiro, Mary (August 15, 2008) The Girl Who Spoke With Pictures: Autism Through Art. (ForeWord Magazine)
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090103022014/http://www.thegirlwhospokewithpictures.com/ill.html Personal website] * [http://www.wfaa.com/video/nspparent-index.html?nvid=353922&shu=1 Not So Perfect Parent: Autism Awareness Month]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.ireport.tv/docs/DOC-236827 CNN feature] * [https://springerlink3.metapress.com/content/b316l01016vw5661/resource-secured/?target=fulltext.html&sid=c3cwhi3xvk3gtrg54m4evnbd&sh=www.springerlink.com] * [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.3109/13682820902733368/abstract;jsessionid=8E300E2014E1DDC936B6A9A10EBDAA59.d02t03] * [http://www.forewordreviews.com/reviews/the-girl-who-spoke-with-pictures/]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} The following is a '''list of notable people diagnosed with [[Crohn's disease]].''' Crohn's disease is a type of [[inflammatory bowel disease]] that may affect any part of the [[Human gastrointestinal tract|gastrointestinal tract]] from [[mouth]] to [[anus]], causing a wide variety of [[symptoms]]. It primarily causes [[abdominal pain]], [[diarrhea]]<!-- PLEASE SEE WP:ENGVAR - DO NOT CHANGE THE SPELLING, AS IT INTERFERES WITH LINKING --> (which may be bloody if inflammation is at its worst), [[vomiting]] (can be continuous), or [[weight loss]],<ref name=Baumgart>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60026-9 |title=Crohn's disease |year=2012 |last1=Baumgart |first1=Daniel C |last2=Sandborn |first2=William J |journal=The Lancet |pmid=22914295 |volume=380 |issue=9853 |pages=1590–605}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/crohns-disease/DS00104/DSECTION=symptoms Crohn's Disease] Mayo Clinic{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://digestive.niddk.nih.gov/ddiseases/pubs/crohns/ Crohn's Disease] National Digestive Diseases Information Clearinghouse</ref> but may also cause complications outside the gastrointestinal tract such as [[skin rashes]], [[arthritis]], [[uveitis|inflammation of the eye]], tiredness, and lack of concentration.<ref name=Baumgart/> <!-- NOTE TO EDITORS
Please cite sources when adding entries to this list, non sourced entries will be removed! -->

{{Chinese name|[[Ma (surname)|Ma]]}} {{Islam and China|figures}} '''Ma Mingxin''' (1719–1781) ({{zh||s=马明心、马明新|t=馬明心、馬明新|p=Mǎ Míngxīn|w=Ma Ming-hsin}}) was a Chinese [[Sufi]] master, the founder of the [[Jahriyya]] ''[[menhuan]]'' ([[Naqshbandi]] [[Sufi order]]).<ref name=mc>{{Cite book |publisher=Harvard Univ Asia Center |year=1996 |isbn=0-674-59497-5 |title=Muslim Chinese: ethnic nationalism in the People's Republic. Volume 149 of Harvard East Asian monographs |edition=2 |author= Dru C. Gladney |authorlink=Dru Gladney |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_hJ9aht6nZQC |pages=48–50 }}</ref> <!--<ref name=tombs48>[http://www2.hawaii.edu/~dru/articles/tombs.pdf Dru C. Gladney, "Muslim Tombs and Ethnic Folklore: Charters for Hui Identity"] ''Journal of Asian Studies'', August 1987, Vol. 46 (3): 495-532; pp. 48-49 in the PDF file.</ref> -->
==Names== Ma Mingxin's Arabic given name was Ibrāhīm. After returning to China from Arabia he started calling himself 'Azīz.<ref name=lipman>{{citation |first=Jonathan Neaman |last=Lipman |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |year=1998 |isbn=962-209-468-6 |title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4_FGPtLEoYQC |pages=86–88 }}</ref>
He was also called Muhammad Emin ({{lang-ar|محمد أمين|}}).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eEwTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA892&dq=dungans+they+form+in+fact+a+distinct+racial+aggregate+with+chinese+and+manchus&hl=en&ei=cRzbTbjdKMSUtwfftL24Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=muhammad%20emin%20ming%20hsin%20150%20years&f=false|title=Encyclopædia of religion and ethics, Volume 8|author1=James Hastings |author2=John Alexander Selbie |author3=Louis Herbert Gray |year=1916|publisher=T. & T. Clark|location=|page=894|isbn=|pages=|accessdate=2010-11-28}}</ref> Followers of the Jahriyyah sometimes refer to him by the title of Wiqāyatullāh ([[Arabic]]: وقاية الله)<ref>{{Cite book|title=心灵史：揭开哲合忍耶的圣域之谜|last=张承志|first=|publisher=风云时代|year=1997|isbn=9789576458033|location=台北市|pages=|quote=《熱什哈尔》中當然不稱呼「馬明心」三字。一般用他的傳教道號「維尕葉 屯拉」，意為「主道的捍衛者」。|via=}}</ref>
==Life== A [[Hui people|Chinese-speaking Muslim]] from [[Gansu]],<ref name=lipman/> Ma Mingxin spent 16 years<ref>Gladney (1996), p. 50. Gladney says, though, that Ma Mingxin "returned after 16 years of study in Yemen and Arabian Peninsula in 1744". Given his dates of life (1719-1781), it would imply that he'd have to start his study in Arabia at 9 - so possibly there is a typo somewhere in that source.</ref> studying in [[Mecca]]<ref name=lipman/> and [[Yemen]]. He was a disciple of a [[Naqshbandi]] [[Sufi]] teacher named 'Abd al-Khāliq,<ref>Lipman (1998), p.202 gives 'Abd al-Khāliq's death date as 1740, without commenting on how that would match with the dates of Ma Mingxin's biography.</ref> who was a son of az-Zayn b. Muhammad 'Abd al-Baqī al-Mizjaji (1643/44-1725), originally of [[Mizjaja]] near [[Zabīd]], [[Yemen]]. Az-Zayn, in his turn, had studied in [[Medina]] under the famous Kurdish mystic Ibrahīm ibn Hasan al-Kūrānī (1616–1690), who was known for advocating the vocal (rather than silent) ''[[dhikr]]'' (invocation of the name of God).<ref name=mc/><ref name=lipman/>
After returning to China in 1761,<ref>Lipman (1998), p. 90</ref> Ma Mingxin founded the [[Jahriyya]] ''[[menhuan]]'' (order) ({{zh|s=哲合忍耶|p=Zhéhérĕnyē|labels=no}}) - the second Naqshbandi order in China after [[Ma Laichi]]'s [[Khufiyya]]. In opposition to the "silent" Khufiyya Sufis, and following al-Kurani's teaching, Jahriyya adherents advocated vocal ''dhikr'', which is reflected in the name of their school (from Arabic ''jahr'', "aloud").<ref name=mc/><ref name=lipman/> Ma Mingxin also opposed the emphasis that the Khufiyya members placed of the veneration of the saints,<ref name=mc/> construction of grandiose elaborately decorated mosques, and the enrichment of religious leaders at the expense of their adherents.<ref name=lipman/>
By the early 1780s, Ma Mingxin's Jahriyya had spread over much of the then province of [[Gansu]] (which at the time also included today's [[Qinghai]] and [[Ningxia]]), as had the late Ma Laichi's Khufiyya ''menhuan''. Theological arguments between members of the two ''menhuans'', as well as the orders' claim on members' contributions, against the background of government mismanagement of the provincial revenue, often resulted in both violent conflicts and lawsuits.<ref name=lipman107>Lipman, pp. 107-111</ref><ref name=lipman96>Lipman, p. 96 (on fiscal mismanagement)</ref>
The escalating conflict between the adherents of the two movements eventually attracted attention of the [[Qing dynasty|Qing]] government in 1781. The apparent center of the conflict at the time was in the ethnic [[Salar people|Salar]] community of [[Xunhua]] County (in today's [[Qinghai]] Province, just west of today's Gansu's [[Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture|Linxia Prefecture]]). Considering the Jahriyya (dubbed by the government ''The New Teaching'', in opposition to the "Old Teaching", i.e. the Khfiyya and the non-Sufi (''gedimu'') Muslims) subversive, the authorities had Ma Mingxin arrested, even though he wasn't personally anywhere around Xunhua at the moment.<ref name=lipman107/>
While Ma Mingxin was kept in [[Lanzhou]] during the [[Jahriyya revolt]], a government expedition sent to Xunhua to take care of the Jahriyya business was destroyed by the Jahriyya Salars, who then rushed across the today's Linxia Prefecture and to the walls of Lanzhou. When the besieged officials brought Ma Mingxin, wearing chains, to the city wall, to show him to the rebels, the Salars at once showed respect and devotion to their imprisoned leaders. Scared officials took Ma down from the wall, and beheaded him right away.<ref name=lipman107/>
Ma Mingxin's widow, whose surname was Zhang (originally, from Gansu's [[Tongwei County]]), and his daughters were exiled to [[Xinjiang]].<ref name=lipman112>Lipman, p. 112</ref>
==Legacy== Ma Mingxin's death did not stop conflicts with China's Muslim community, or those between the Muslims and the government. Three years after the death of Ma Mingxin, his follower Tian Wu started a rebellion against the imperial government; after its defeat, the authorities remained on lookout against the spread of the "subversive" Jahriyya teachings.<ref name=mc/>
Ma Mingxin's fifth generation descendant and the then leader of Jahriyya, [[Ma Hualong]], was one of the chief leaders of the [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|Great Northwest Hui Rebellion]] in Ningxia, Shaanxi, and Gansu in the 1860s.<ref>Gladney (1996), p. 50. Other sources, however, don't mention Ma Hualong's descent from Ma Mingxin, so possibly Gladney means "spiritual successor" (via Jahriyya's ''[[silsilah]]'') when describin Ma Hualong as a "descendant" of Ma Mingxin.</ref>
The Jahriyya order continues to this day, even if in more covert forms.<ref name=mc/> In remembrance of Ma Mingxin, whose beard was shorn by government soldiers before his execution, many Jahriyya members shave the sides of their beards.<ref name=g53>Gladney (1996), pp. 52-53</ref>
In 1985, over 20,000 [[Hui people|Chinese Muslims]] assembled at the site of Ma Mingxin's original (destroyed) tomb near [[Lanzhou]] for a commemoration ceremony. The [[Gongbei (Islamic architecture)|tomb]] has since been rebuilt.<ref name=g53/>
Ma Mingxin's descendant was [[Ma Yuanzhang]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Jonathan N. Lipman|title=Familiar Strangers: A History of Muslims in Northwest China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8Nzux7z6KAC&pg=PA179#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=1 July 2011|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-80055-4|pages=179}}</ref>
[[Ma Shaowu]] was a fourth generation descendants of Ma Mingxin, and Ma Shaowu's uncle Ma Yuanzhang was also a descendent, as was Ma Shaowu's great uncle Ma Shenglin {{lang|zh-Hans|马圣鳞}}. Ma Shaowu's son Ma Cho-ya is a fifth generation descendant and he currently lives in [[Urumqi]].<ref name="Garnaut">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ouigour.fr/recherches_et_analyses/Garnautpage_93.pdf |title=From Yunnan to Xinjiang:Governor Yang Zengxin and his Dungan Generals |last=Garnaut |first=Anthony |publisher=Pacific and Asian History, Australian National University) |accessdate=2010-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309054654/http://www.ouigour.fr/recherches_et_analyses/Garnautpage_93.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-09 |df= }}</ref>

{{Infobox American Indian chief |name = Mangas Coloradas |image = "Human Science" by Orson Squire Fowler.jpg |caption = Drawing of Skull of Mangas Coloradas from 1873 book "Human Science" p. 1196 by [[Orson Squire Fowler]] |tribe = [[Mimbreño]] [[Apache people|Apache]] |birth_date = c. 1793 |birth_place = |death_date = January 18, {{death year and age|1863|1793}} |successor = [[Delgadito (Apache chief)|Delgadito]] (killed 1864) |rank= [[Tribal chief|Chief]] |battles=[[Apache Wars]] * [[Bascom Affair]] * [[Battle of Apache Pass]] }}
'''Mangas Coloradas''' or '''Mangus-Colorado'''<!-- spelling used in Geronimo's memoirs--> ('''La-choy Ko-kun-noste''', alias "Red Sleeve"), or '''Dasoda-hae''' ("He Just Sits There") (c. 1793 – January 18, 1863) was an [[Apache]] [[tribal chief]] and a member of the [[Mimbreño]] (Tchihende) division of the Central Apaches, whose homeland stretched west from the [[Rio Grande]] to include most of what is present-day southwestern [[New Mexico]]. He was the father-in-law of the [[Chiricahua]] (Tsokanende) Chief [[Cochise]], the Mimbreño Chief [[Victorio]] and the Mescalero (Sehende) Chief Kutu-hala or Kutbhalla (probably to be identified with [[Caballero (Apache chief)|Caballero]]), and is regarded by many historians to be one of the most important [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] leaders of the 19th century due to his fighting achievements against the [[Mexico|Mexicans]] and [[United States|Americans]].
The name ''Mangas Coloradas'' is the reception of his Apache nickname '''Kan-da-zis Tlishishen''' ("Red Shirt" or "Pink Shirt") by the Mexicans and is Spanish for '''Red Sleeves'''. A Bedonkohe (''Bi-dan-ku'' – 'In Front of the End People', ''Bi-da-a-naka-enda'' – 'Standing in front of the enemy') by birth he married into the Copper Mines local group of the Tchihende and became the principal chief of the whole Tchihende Apache division, including the neighboring Mimbreño local group of the Warm Springs Tchihende, directly led by the famous chief [[Cuchillo Negro]] (in Apache language '''Baishan'''), second chief of the whole Tchihende Apache division and his long-time companion.
[[Image:Mangas Colorados1.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Mangas Coloradas' son and namesake (1884).<ref>[http://www.legendsofamerica.com/picturepages/na-apache6-mangascoloradas.html Legends of America: Mangas Coloradas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120428171711/http://www.legendsofamerica.com/picturepages/na-apache6-mangascoloradas.html |date=2012-04-28 }}</ref>]]
==Apache war-leader and chief== During the decades of the 1820s and 1830s, the Apaches' main enemy were the Mexicans, who had won their independence from [[Spain]] in 1821. By 1835, [[Mexico]] had placed a bounty on Apache scalps. After [[Juan José Compa]], the leader of the Coppermine Mimbreño Apaches, was killed for bounty money in 1837 in the massacre at Santa Rita del Cobre, Mangas became a war leader and a chief, and, joining forces with his friend and long-time companion (and possibly brother-in-law) [[Cuchillo Negro]] (Spanish: Black Knife),{{efn-ua|His father Fuerte, a.k.a. Soldado Fiero (Spanish: Proud Soldier), had been killed near Santa Rita del Cobre by troops from the Janos garrison in 1835 or 1837}} began a series of retaliatory raids against the Mexicans, killing and destroying all around the mining town and placing Santa Rita under siege, finally attacking the column of fleeing Mexicans and slaughtering a large number. Mangas Coloradas became the principal leader of the Coppermine Mimbreños, and led them for about 25 years, while Cuchillo Negro led the Warm Springs Mimbreños.
In 1846, when the United States went to war with Mexico, the Apache Nation promised U.S. soldiers safe passage through Apache lands. Once the U.S. occupied [[New Mexico]] in 1846, Mangas Coloradas signed a peace treaty, respecting them as conquerors of the hated Mexican enemy. An uneasy peace between the Apache and the United States lasted until an influx of gold miners into New Mexico's Pinos Altos Mountains led to open conflict.
In 1851 the settlement at Santa Rita del Cobre of the U.S. delegation (with General J.R. Bartlett) in the Mexican-American Border Commission, and the reopening of the Santa Rita del Cobre copper mines, effected the meeting with the Anglo-American newcomers. Mangas Coloradas, like Cuchillo Negro, [[Delgadito (Apache chief)|Delgadito]], Ponce, Coleto Amarillo and all the most important Tchihende and Ndendahe chiefs, had to face new problems. In June 1851 Mangas Coloradas, with Delgadito, Ponce and Coleto Amarillo, went to [[Santa Rita del Cobre]] to meet Bartlett, and the discussions continued until the Apaches no longer felt disappointed and betrayed by the newcomers. According to John C. Cremony's book, ''Life Among the Apaches'', in 1861, near Pinos Altos mining camp, Mangas Coloradas was attacked by a group of White miners who tied him to a tree and severely flogged him.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} Yet historian Edwin R. Sweeney finds issue with this claim in his biography of the chief: if it was true, probably Geronimo, who spent a great deal of time with Mangas Coloradas during the 1850s and 1860s, would have mentioned that to his biographer as a reason for the war, yet he did not.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} The killing of Cuchillo Negro by U.S. troops at Canyon de los Muertos Carneros in May 1857 was an even more bitter business.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
In December 1860, 30 miners launched a surprise attack on an encampment of Bedonkohes on the west bank of the [[Mimbres River]]. Historian Edwin R. Sweeney reported, the miners ''"... killed four Indians, wounded others, and captured thirteen women and children."'' Shortly after that, Mangas began raids against U.S. citizens and their property.
Mangas Coloradas' daughter Dos-Teh-Seh married Cochise, principal chief of the Tsokanende or Chiricahua Apache. In early February 1861, US Army Lieutenant George N. Bascom, investigating the "Indian" kidnapping of a rancher's son, apparently without orders, lured an innocent Cochise, his family and several warriors into a trap at [[Apache Pass]], southeastern [[Arizona]]. Cochise managed to escape, but his family and warriors remained in custody. Negotiations were unsuccessful and fighting erupted. This incident, known as the "[[Bascom Affair]]", ended with Cochise's brother and five other warriors being hanged by Bascom. Later that year, Mangas Coloradas and Cochise struck an alliance, agreeing to drive all Americans out of Apache territory. They were joined in their effort by middle-aged [[Delgadito (Apache chief)|Delgadito]] and [[Nana (chief)|Nana]], [[Victorio]], [[Juh]] and [[Geronimo]]. Although the goal was never achieved, the White population in Apache territory was greatly reduced for a few years during the Civil War, after federal troops had been withdrawn to the east.
==Death== In the summer of 1862, after recovering from a bullet wound in the chest, Mangas Coloradas met with an intermediary to call for peace. In January 1863, he decided to meet with U.S. military leaders at Fort McLane ([[Apache Tejo]]), in southwestern [[New Mexico]]. He was promised provisions in return for peace, and he returned with his people.<ref>Geronimo, S.M. Barrett ''Geronimo: The True Story of America's Most Ferocious Warrior'', 1906, republished 2011 {{isbn|1616087536}}, p. 73-74</ref> Mangas arrived under a flag of truce to meet with Brigadier General [[Joseph Rodman West]], an officer of the California militia and a future [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]] senator from [[Louisiana]]. Armed soldiers took Mangas into custody. West gave an execution order to the sentries. [[Image:Orson Squire Fowler.jpg|thumb|200px|Orson Squire Fowler]]
{{quote|Men, that old murderer has got away from every soldier command and has left a trail of blood for 500 miles on the old stage line. I want him dead tomorrow morning. Do you understand? I want him dead.}}
That night, Mangas was tortured, shot and killed "escaping". While tied on the ground, Mangas was provoked with red hot bayonets until he moved to simulate his attempt to escape.<ref>Waters, Frank. ''Brave Are My People''. Santa Fe, NM: Clear Light Publishers, 1993.</ref>
The following day, U.S. soldiers, fascinated by the size of the Apache (Mangas was 6 feet, 6 inches tall), cut off his head, boiled it and sent the skull to [[Orson Squire Fowler]], a phrenologist in New York City. Phrenological analysis of the skull and two sketches of it appear in Fowler's book.<ref>Fowler, O.S. 1873. Human Science or Phrenology. p. 1196. (Available at [https://archive.org/stream/humanscienceorph00fowl#page/1196/mode/1up])</ref> Daklugie, one of informants in Eve Ball's book,<ref name=Indeh>{{cite book|author1=Ball, Eve |author2=Henn, Nora |author3=Sanchez, Lynda A. | title=Indeh: An Apache Odyssey (reprint)|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=1988|isbn=0-8061-2165-3}}</ref> said the skull went to the [[Smithsonian Institution]].
However, the Smithsonian has done a thorough search for the skull, and reports that it never received it. Mangas' descendants and sources based on their testimony may have confused the Smithsonian with Fowler's Phrenological Cabinet in New York, where the skull was on display, leading to the misattribution. Another possible fate of the skull was that it was returned to the Apaches by the Smithsonian in a 1990 transfer, but was not individually labeled.<ref>[http://www.snowwowl.com/swolfjworleychiefs2.html The Apaches: Destined for Change]</ref>
The murder and mutilation of Mangas' body only increased the hostility between Apaches and the United States, resulting in war continuing for nearly another 25 years.
==Appearances in literature== * ''[[Life Among the Apaches]]'' (1868) by [[John C. Cremony]] * ''[[The Bandits from Rio Frio]]'' (1889) by [[Manuel Payno]] * ''[[Apache (novel)|Apache]]'' (1931) by [[Will Levington Comfort]] * ''[[Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee]]'' (1970) by [[Dee Brown (writer)|Dee Brown]] * ''[[Flashman and the Redskins]]'' (1982) by [[George MacDonald Fraser]] * ''[[Blood Meridian]]'' (1985) by [[Cormac McCarthy]] * ''Firestar by Coyote'' (2011) by A.A. Randazzo * "[[Indeh]]" (2016) by [[Ethan Hawke]]
==Cinematic references==
The 1952 film "Lone Star" starring Clark Gable, featured Magnus Coloradus, played by Chief Yowlachie, among a group of Apaches, including a child named Geronimo, sitting west of the Pecos with Sam Houston.
The film ''[[War Drums]]'', was a 1957 American Western film directed by Reginald Le Borg and written by Gerald Drayson Adams. It featured Lex Barker as Mangas Coloradas, Joan Taylor and Ben Johnson. The friendship between a white man and an Apache chief is tested when they fall in love with the same woman during a time of frontier conflict.
The 2006 Australian film ''[[Last Train to Freo]]'', directed by ''[[Jeremy Sims]]'', features a tattoo of "Red Sleeves" on the Tall Thug's arm, played by ''[[Steve Le Marquand]]''. He then begins a short monologue, detailing the life of the Apache War Chief, in an attempt to gain the attention of Lisa, played by ''[[Gigi Edgley]]''.
The 2013 film ''[[Avenged (2013 U.S. film)|Avenged]]'', directed by Michael Ojeda, features the vengeful ghost of Mangas Coloradas as possessing a young woman's body and wreaking vengeance upon the descendants of General Joseph Rodman West.
==Further reading== * Etulain, Richard W. ''New Mexican Lives: A Biographical History''. University of New Mexico Center for the American West, [[University of New Mexico Press]], 2002. {{ISBN|0-8263-2433-9}} * Haley, James L. ''Apaches: A History and Culture Portrait''. [[University of Oklahoma Press]], 1997. {{ISBN|0-8061-2978-6}} * Sweeney, Edwin R. ''Mangas Coloradas: Chief of the Chiricahua Apaches''. [[University of Oklahoma Press]], 1998. {{ISBN|0-8061-3063-6}} * Yarbrough, Leroy. 1968. ''The Apache and the Sioux''. REAL WEST magazine
==References== {{Notelist-ua}} {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{FAG|8952352|Mangas-Coloradas|work=Native American Tribal Chief|author=Bedford W. Sipes|date=Jun 18, 2004|accessdate=Aug 18, 2011}} *[http://www.desertusa.com/ind1/Colradas.html Jay W. Sharp. The Night They Shot Mangas Colradas. Desert USA.]
{{Authority control}}

{{short description|American biologist}} {{Infobox person | name = Marc Bekoff | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1945|09|06}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], New York | residence = | nationality = | education = AB (1967), [[Washington University]]
MA (1968), [[Hofstra University]]
PhD (1972, animal behavior), Washington University | occupation = Professor Emeritus of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, [[University of Colorado, Boulder]] | known_for = | awards = | website = {{URL|http://marcbekoff.publishpath.com}} }} '''Marc Bekoff''' (born September 6, 1945) is Professor Emeritus of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at the [[University of Colorado, Boulder]].[http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-3413200047/bekoff-marc-1945.html "Bekoff, Marc 1945–]," HighBeam Research. He is the co-founder, with [[Jane Goodall]], of Ethologists for the Ethical Treatment of Animals,[http://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/marc-bekoff-phd "Marc Bekoff, Ph.D."], ''Psychology Today'', undated. a fellow of the [[Animal Behavior Society]] and a former [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim fellow]]. He lectures internationally on animal behavior, [[cognitive ethology]] (the study of animal minds), and [[behavioral ecology]], and writes a science column about animal emotion for ''Psychology Today''.[http://www.literati.net/authors/marc-bekoff/ "Marc Bekoff"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213071706/http://www.literati.net/authors/marc-bekoff |date=2013-02-13 }}, literati.net, undated. *Marc Bekoff, [http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions "Animal emotions"], ''Psychology Today''. Bekoff is a [[Veganism|vegan]].Marc Bekoff, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marc-bekoff/vegans-shouldnt-eat-oyste_b_605786.html "Vegans Shouldn't Eat Oysters, and If You Do You're Not Vegan, So... "], ''Huffington Post'', June 10, 2010. He is also a patron of the Captive Animals Protection Society, a charity campaigning against the [[exotic pet]] trade, and the use of non-human animals in circuses and zoos.[http://www.captiveanimals.org/about-us/who-we-are "Professor Marc Bekoff – Patron"], Captive Animals Protection Society. In May 2010 he argued in an article for the [[Greater Good Science Center]], "Expanding Our Compassionate Footprint," that human beings need to abandon [[Anthropocentrism|human exceptionalism]]: "Research on animal morality is blossoming, and if we can break free of theoretical prejudices, we may come to better understand ourselves and the other animals with whom we share this planet."Marc Bekoff, [http://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/expanding_our_compassion_footprint "Expanding Our Compassion Footprint"], Greater Good Science Center, May 20, 2010. ==Selected works== Bekoff has written over 1000 articles and published 30 books, and has edited three encyclopedias. His books include the following: * ''Species of mind: The philosophy and biology of cognitive ethology'' (with Colin Allen, 1997). * ''Nature's purposes: Analyses of function and design in biology'' (edited with Colin Allen and [[George V. Lauder|George Lauder]], 1998) * ''Animal play: Evolutionary, comparative, and ecological perspectives'' (edited with John Byers, 1998) * ''Encyclopedia of animal rights and animal welfare'' (1998) * ''The cognitive animal: Empirical and theoretical perspectives on animal cognition'' (edited by Marc Bekoff, Colin Allen, and Gordon Burghardt, 2002) * ''Minding animals: Awareness, emotions, and heart'' (2002) * ''The Ten Trusts: What we must do to care for the animals we love'' (Jane Goodall and Marc Bekoff, 2002) * ''Animals Matter: A Biologist Explains Why We Should Treat Animals with Compassion and Respect'' (2007) * ''The Emotional Lives of Animals: A Leading Scientist Explores Animal Joy, Sorrow, and Empathy and Why They Matter'' (2007) * ''Wild Justice: The Moral Lives of Animals'' (Marc Bekoff and [[Jessica Pierce]], 2009) {{ISBN|978-0-226-04161-2}} * ''The Animal Manifesto: Six Reasons For Expanding Our Compassion Footprint'' (2010) * ''Ignoring Nature No More: The Case for Compassionate Conservation'' (edited by Marc Bekoff, 2013) * ''Rewilding Our Hearts: Building Pathways of Compassion and Coexistence'' (2014) * ''The Jane Effect: Celebrating Jane Goodall'' (edited with Dale Peterson, [[Trinity University Press]], 2015)http://tupress.org/books/the-jane-effect * ''Canine Confidential: Why Dogs Do What They Do'' (University of Chicago Press, 2018) {{ISBN|978-0-226-56049-6}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ethologicalethics.org/ Ethologists for the Ethical Treatment of Animals / Citizens for Responsible Animal Behavior Studies] * [https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animal-emotions Blog] at ''[[Psychology Today]]'' {{animal rights}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bekoff, Marc}} [[Category:American biologists]] [[Category:Animal welfare scholars]] [[Category:Ethologists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Colorado Boulder faculty]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Vegetarians]]
