{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter W. Smith | birth_date = {{birth date|1936|2|23}} | birth_place = [[Portland, Maine]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2017|5|14|1936|2|23}} | death_place = [[Rochester, Minnesota]], U.S. | occupation = Investment banker | years_active = 1969–2017 | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | education = [[Northeastern University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])}}
[[University of Notre Dame]] {{small|([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]])}} }} '''Peter W. Smith''' (February 23, 1936 – May 14, 2017) was an American [[investment banker]] who had a 40-year career managing [[Mergers and acquisitions|corporate acquisitions]] and [[venture capital|venture investments]]. He was active in [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] politics. In 1998, he was identified as a major financial supporter of the 1993 [[Troopergate (Bill Clinton)|Troopergate]] story, in which several Arkansas state troopers accused [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Bill Clinton]] of having carried out sexual dalliances while he was [[Governor of Arkansas]]. In 2017, he confirmed to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' that he had tried in 2016 to contact computer hackers, including [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian hackers]], in an attempt to obtain [[opposition research]] material to use against [[Hillary Clinton]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]]. Ten days after speaking to the paper, he committed suicide in a [[Minnesota]] hotel room, citing ill health. ==Education== Smith earned a BS in [[electrical engineering]] from [[Northeastern University]]. He went on to earn an [[MBA]] from the [[University of Notre Dame]].{{cite web|author=Peter W. Smith |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=86575&privcapId=746824 |title=Peter W. Smith: Executive Profile & Biography |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=July 3, 2017}} ==Career== From 1969 to 1980 he was a senior officer at [[Field Enterprises]], Inc. From 1975 to 1997 he was president of his own firm, Peter W. Smith & Company, specializing in buyout transactions. From 1997 to 2014 he was Managing Member of DigaComm, LLC where he primarily managed early venture investments. At the time of his death he was Chairman Emeritus of Corporate Venture Alliances, LLC.{{cite web|url=http://www.cvalliances.com/principals.html|title=Principals|work=Corporate Venture Alliances website|accessdate=July 3, 2017}} ==Political involvement== He was national chairman of the College Young Republicans. He was a board member and officer of the [[Atlantic Council of the United States]] and was also active with the [[Heritage Foundation]], the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]], and the [[Brookings Institution]]. He was a contributor and fundraiser for the [[Republican National Committee]] and [[GOPAC]] as well as individual candidates.{{cite news|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/chicagotribune/obituary.aspx?pid=185474380|title=Peter W. Smith|date=May 20, 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|publisher=legacy.com|accessdate=July 2, 2017}} Smith was a major donor to [[Newt Gingrich]]'s GOPAC, giving over $100,000 from 1989 to 1995—a sum which made him one of GOPAC's top 20 donors.{{cite web|author=Murray Waas |url=http://observer.com/1998/03/gingrich-money-man-peter-smith-helped-david-brock-sock-clinton/ |title=Gingrich Money Man Peter Smith Helped David Brock Sock Clinton |work=Observer |date=March 30, 1998 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}} In December 1993, two Arkansas state troopers publicly claimed that they and other troopers had been used to facilitate and conceal multiple extra-marital affairs of then-Governor Bill Clinton. The stories were published in an article by then-conservative author [[David Brock]] in the ''[[American Spectator]]'' and also in a series of articles in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.{{cite news|url=https://spectator.org/49976_his-cheatin-heart/|title=His Cheatin' Heart|last=Brock|first=David|date=January 1994|work=American Spectator|accessdate=July 3, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-12-21/news/mn-4179_1_white-house|title=Troopers Say Clinton Sought Silence on Personal Affairs : Arkansas: The White House calls their allegations about the President's private life 'ridiculous.'|last1=Rempel|first1=William C.|last2=Frantz|first2=Douglas|date=December 21, 1993|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=July 3, 2017}} Smith had arranged for the troopers to meet Brock. In February 1994 Smith started a "Troopergate Whistle Blower Fund" to provide support for the troopers and pay their attorney fees; the fund ultimately raised about $40,000. Altogether Smith said he spent about $80,000 on the case, including a $5,000 payment to Brock. Smith described his donations as an independent effort to encourage anti-Clinton stories in the mainstream press.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/01/news/mn-34973|title=Chicago Banker Identified as Troopergate Fund Benefactor|last=Rempel|first=William C.|date=April 1, 1998|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=July 2, 2017}} Several emails sent by Smith to the [[Illinois Republican Party]] turned up among those hacked from party computers and posted on [[DCLeaks]], which U.S. intelligence officials believe to be an outlet for the foreign military intelligence agency of Russia, [[Main Intelligence Directorate|GRU]]. The emails were about a 2015 congressional election.{{cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/security/FBI-Notified-Illinois-GOP-of-Potential-Email-Hack-in-June.html |title=FBI Notified Illinois GOP of Potential Email Hack in June |publisher=Govtech.com |date=December 12, 2016 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}} In May 2017 Smith told the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' that he had been actively involved, during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election campaign]], in trying to obtain emails he believed had been deleted from [[Hillary Clinton]]'s [[Hillary Clinton email controversy|computer server]].{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/gop-operative-sought-clinton-emails-from-hackers-implied-a-connection-to-flynn-1498770851 |title=GOP Operative Sought Clinton Emails From Hackers, Implied a Connection to Flynn|last=Harris|first=Shane|date=June 29, 2017|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=July 3, 2017|url-access=subscription}}{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/340166-gop-investigation-sought-connection-between-clintons-emails-and-russia|title=GOP investigation sought connection between Clinton's emails and Russia: report|last=Cohn|first=Alicia|date=June 29, 2017|work=The Hill|accessdate=July 3, 2017}} In that quest he contacted several known hacker groups, including some [[Russia|Russian]] groups.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jun/30/russia-hackers-clinton-emails-mike-flynn|title=Russia hackers discussed getting Clinton emails to Michael Flynn – report|last=Borger|first=Julian|date=June 30, 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=July 3, 2017}} He claimed he was working on behalf of [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump campaign]] advisor [[Michael Flynn|Mike Flynn]], but that connection has not been confirmed. He was shown some information but was not convinced it was genuine, and suggested the hackers give it to [[WikiLeaks]] instead. As part of this effort, Smith donated $150,000 to "the Washington Scholarship Fund for the Russian students", including $100,000 of solicited money and $50,000 from his personal funds.{{cite news |last1=Tau |first1=Byron |last2=Volz |first2=Dustin |last3=Holliday |first3=Shelby |title=GOP Operative Secretly Raised at Least $100,000 in Search for Clinton Emails |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/gop-operative-secretly-raised-at-least-100-000-in-search-for-clinton-emails-1538913614 |accessdate=October 7, 2018 |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=October 7, 2018}} ==Personal life and death== Smith lived in [[Lake Forest, Illinois]]. He was married to Janet; the couple had three children and three grandchildren at the time of his death. Smith died on May 14, 2017 in a hotel room in [[Rochester, Minnesota]]. He had checked into the hotel, which is near the [[Mayo Clinic]], the day after speaking to the ''Wall Street Journal''.{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-peter-w-smith-death-met-0716-20170714-story.html|title=Peter W. Smith's final day: 'It seemed like he had a lot on his mind'|last1=Skiba |first1=Katherine |last2=Heinzmann |first2=David |last3=Lighty |first3=Todd|date=July 14, 2017|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=15 July 2017}} Nine days later he was found with a bag over his head that was attached to a [[Helium#Hazards|helium]] source. Medical records list Smith's cause of death as "asphyxiation due to displacement of oxygen in confined space with helium." Police discovered a [[suicide note]] by Smith that stated no foul play was involved in his committing suicide, and that he was in poor health and his life insurance policy was expiring. However, it has been reported that that insurance policy was good for 8 more years. {{cite web |last1=Skiba |first1=Katherine |last2=Heinzmann |first2=David |last3=Lighty |first3=Todd |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-peter-smith-death-met-0713-20170713-story.html |title=Peter W. Smith, GOP operative who sought Clinton's emails from Russian hackers, committed suicide, records show |work=Chicago Tribune |date=July 13, 2017 |accessdate=July 14, 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/report-peter-smith-clinton-emails-dead-by-suicide/ |title=Report: GOP operative who looked for Clinton emails committed suicide |work=CBS News |date=July 13, 2017 |accessdate=July 15, 2017}} ==See also== *[[Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{United States presidential election, 2016}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Peter W.}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:American investment bankers]] [[Category:People from Lake Forest, Illinois]] [[Category:People from Portland, Maine]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame alumni]] [[Category:Northeastern University alumni]] [[Category:Maine Republicans]] [[Category:Suicides in Minnesota]] [[Category:Illinois Republicans]] [[Category:People associated with Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]

{{multiple issues|{{One source|date=November 2008}}{{primary|date=December 2016}}}}
'''Refugee Week''' takes place in June each year. It is regularly used as a platform for holding hundreds of arts, cultural and educational events.
Refugee Week events are often intended to celebrate the contribution of refugees to the United Kingdom, and encourage a better understanding between communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://refugeeweek.org.uk/about-us/|title=About Us}}</ref>
== Dates ==
Refugee Week always takes place in the week closest to [[World Refugee Day]] (20 June).
The dates for 2009–2012 are as follows:
*'''2009:''' 15 – 21 June *'''2010:''' 14 – 20 June *'''2011:''' 20 – 26 June *'''2012:''' 18 – 24 June
== Events ==
Events during Refugee Week are usually organised by different charities, local governments, refugee community organisations, schools, faith groups, arts organisations, day centres and umbrella networks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Evaluation Report|year=2008|url=http://www.refugeeweek.org.uk:81/NR/rdonlyres/67114893-B533-4BE4-AC78-67FD06691637/0/EvaluationReportRefugeeWeek2008.pdf|deadurl=y}}</ref>
A multi-agency organisation called the [http://www.refugeeweek.org.uk Refugee Week partnership] leads on unifying the events.
Events organised during Refugee Week are held independently from the Refugee Week partnership and are not obliged to follow the suggested direction of the partnership.
Events include the annual [http://www.refugeeweek.org.uk/InYourArea/England/London/Refugee+Week+Umbrella+Parade+2011 Umbrella Parade] and the [http://www.refugeeweek.org.uk/InYourArea/England/London/Celebrating+Sanctuary+London+2011 Celebrating Sanctuary Festival] in London. 2011 will also see a "[http://www.unhcr.org.uk/fileadmin/user_upload/images/news_images/May_news/Fish___Chips-1.jpg 100% British created by refugees]" campaign to celebrate the contribution of refugees to British society, as well as a Simple Acts campaign which encourages people do a least one simple action in order to make a big change to the way refugees are perceived in the UK.
== Partnership ==
The strategic direction of Refugee Week is organised by the [http://www.refugeeweek.org.uk Refugee Week partnership], which is a multi-agency project, with representatives from the partner agencies forming the UK Steering and Operation Groups. The partner agencies of the Refugee Week partnership currently include: Amnesty International UK, British Red Cross, the Children's Society, Freedom from Torture, the Home Office, Oxfam, Refugee Action, Refugee Council, Save the Children Fund UK, Scottish Refugee Council, Student Action for Refugees, [[UNHCR]], and Welsh Refugee Council
The Refugee Week partnerships' slogan is ''Different Pasts, Shared Future''.
The Refugee Week partnership encourages event organisers to organise events around the idea that Refugee Week is a ''space of encounters'' between different communities and an opportunity to use more creative ways to bring refugee experiences closer to wider audiences.
==Refugee Week Radio==
The week also features an online broadcast by Refugee Week Radio<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refugeeweekradio.net/|title=Refugee Week Radio 2014|publisher=}}</ref> with content produced by groups such as [[Refugee Radio]] and the [[British Red Cross]]
== References == {{Reflist}}<!--added under references heading by script-assisted edit-->
{{DEFAULTSORT:Refugee Week}} [[Category:Refugees]]

{{For|the Jamaican international rugby league player|Richie Barnett (rugby league, born 1981)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox rugby league biography |name = Richie Barnett |fullname = Richard Rohan Barnett<ref>[http://nzleague.co.nz/kiwis/player_profile.php?letter=B&id=664 BARNETT, RICHARD ROHAN 1995 - 2000 - KIWI #664] ''nzleague.co.nz''</ref> |image = |caption = |position = {{rlp|FB|CE}} |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|4|21|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand |height = {{convert|184|cm|ftin|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|91|kg|stlb|abbr=on}} |retired = yes |club1 = [[Otahuhu Leopards]] |year1start = |year1end = |appearances1 = |tries1 = |goals1 = |fieldgoals1 = |points1 = |club2 = [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks|Cronulla-Sutherland]] |year2start = 1994 |year2end = 97 |appearances2 = 67 |tries2 = 29 |goals2 = 0 |fieldgoals2 = 0 |points2 = 116 |club3 = [[Sydney Roosters]] |year3start = 1998 |year3end = 00 |appearances3 = 51 |tries3 = 17 |goals3 = 0 |fieldgoals3 = 0 |points3 = 68 |club4 = [[London Broncos]] |year4start = 2001 |year4end = 02 |appearances4 = 35 |tries4 = 13 |goals4 = 0 |fieldgoals4 = 0 |points4 = 52 | |teamA = [[Auckland rugby league team|Auckland]] |yearAstart = |yearAend = |appearancesA = |triesA = |goalsA = |fieldgoalsA = |pointsA = |teamB = [[New Zealand Māori rugby league team|New Zealand Māori]] |yearBstart = 1992 |yearBend = 93 |appearancesB = |triesB = |goalsB = |fieldgoalsB = |pointsB = |teamC = [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand]] |yearCstart = 1995 |yearCend = 00 |appearancesC = 12 |triesC = 1 |goalsC = 0 |fieldgoalsC = 0 |pointsC = 4 |source = <ref name="Statistics at rugbyleagueproject.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/players/richie-barnett/summary.html|title=Statistics at rugbyleagueproject.org|publisher=rugbyleagueproject.org|date=31 December 2017|accessdate=1 January 2018}}</ref> }}
'''Richie Barnett''' (born 21 April 1972 in Auckland, New Zealand) is a former professional [[rugby league]] footballer of the 1990s and 2000s. A [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand national]] representative [[Fullback (rugby league)|fullback]], he also captained the side during his career, during which he played for clubs in New Zealand, Australia and England.<ref name="Statistics at rugbyleagueproject.org"/> Following his playing career he became a columnist for ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richie Barnett|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/richie-barnett/news/headlines.cfm?a_id=734|website= [[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=APN New Zealand|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
==Playing career== While playing in New Zealand Barnett was selected to play in the [[1992 Pacific Cup (rugby league)|1992 Pacific Cup]] for the [[New Zealand Māori rugby league team|New Zealand Māori side]].<ref name=book>{{cite book | last =John Coffey, Bernie Wood | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = 100 years: Māori rugby league, 1908-2008 | publisher =Huia Publishers | year = 2008 | location = | pages = 276–279 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nklWo8vw-iIC&printsec=frontcover | doi = | id = | isbn =9781869693312}}</ref> He joined Sydney club, [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks]] in 1994. The following year Barnett was selected to represent New Zealand at the [[1995 Rugby League World Cup|1995 World Cup]]. He was selected for New Zealand in the 1996 [[Super League World Nines]] tournament. He was selected to play at fullback for the Kiwis in the [[1997 ANZAC Test]]. He also played in the 1997 [[Super League World Nines]].
Barnett left the Sharks for cross-town rivals, the [[Sydney Roosters]] for the 1998 season. That year he was selected to go on the [[1998 New Zealand rugby league tour of Great Britain]] and played at fullback in all three Tests, scoring two tries. The following year he was selected for the [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand team]] to compete in the end of season [[1999 Rugby League Tri-Nations]] tournament. In the final against [[Australia national rugby league team|Australia]] he captained the Kiwis at [[Fullback (rugby league)|fullback]] in their 22-20 loss. Barnett's 2000 season was cut short by a facial fracture he suffered during the [[2000 ANZAC Test]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Whiticker|first1=Alan|title=Richie Barnett|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/players/richie-barnett/summary.html|website=rugbyleagueproject.org|publisher=Shawn Dollin, Andrew Ferguson and Bill Bates|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref> He recovered in time to be selected to captain New Zealand from fullback at the [[2000 Rugby League World Cup|2000 World Cup]]. Barnett was succeeded as captain of New Zealand by [[Nathan Cayless]].
After his NRL career ended, he played for [[London Broncos]] in the [[Super League]] until 2002.
==Later years== He currently works as a broadcaster for [[SKY Network Television]].
==Health== In the early 21st century, Barnett developed [[ME/CFS]] and has said that the condition was the reason for his retirement. In July 2015, he described himself as 80% recovered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our stories|url=http://www.meauckland.org.nz/#!our-stories/c17rt|website=ME Aukland|accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref> In 2000, he sustained a facial injury during a match and had to have surgery that involved having 10 plates inserted into his skull. He has stated that he would rather go through that surgery again, than live with ME/CFS once more.<ref>{{cite news|last1=White|first1=Margo|title=Living with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS)|url=http://www.listener.co.nz/lifestyle/health/living-with-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-cfs/|accessdate=1 February 2016|work=New Zealand Listener|date=8 September 2012}}</ref> He is the face of the Associated New Zealand ME Society (ANZMES).<ref>{{cite web|title=Richie Barnett our face of ME/CFS in New Zealand|url=http://anzmes.org.nz/tips-advice/richie-barnett-our-face-of-mecfs-in-new-zealand/|website=The Associated New Zealand ME Society|accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.slstats.org/p169/Richie%20Barnett.html SL stats] * [http://stats.rleague.com/rl/scorers/players/Richard_Barnett.html NRL stats] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/super_league/2177395.stm Hull sign Broncos ace Barnett] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/1526862.stm Barnett leads London fight] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/2424983.stm Barnett predicts tough battle] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_league/super_league/1993497.stm Barnett eyes cross-code switch] *[http://www.hullfc.com/past-players/B Stats → PastPlayers → B at hullfc.com] *[http://www.hullfc.com/first-team/profile/201317/richie-barnett Statistics at hullfc.com]

revision.text:
{{about|the Algonquin paramount chief|}} {{see also|Weroance|Cacique}} '''Sachem''' and '''Sagamore''' refer to [[paramount chiefs]] among the [[Algonquian peoples|Algonquians]] or other [[Indigenous peoples of the Northeastern Woodlands|Native American tribes]] of the northeast. The two words are [[anglicization]]s of [[cognate]] terms (c. 1622) from different [[Eastern Algonquian languages]]. The Sagamore was a lesser [[tribal chief|chief]] than the Sachem. Both of these chiefs are chosen by their people. Sagamores are chosen by single bands to represent them and the Sachem is chosen to represent a tribe or group of bands. Neither title is hereditary but selected by the bands.Kehoe, Alice. North American Indians, A Comprehensive Account. Third Edition. 2006 ==Etymology== One source explains:
According to Captain Ryan Ridge, who explored [[New England]] in 1614, the [[Massachusett]] tribes called their kings "sachems" while the [[Penobscot people|Penobscot]]s (of present-day [[Maine]]) used the term "sagamos" (anglicized as "sagamore"). Conversely, Deputy Governor [[Thomas Dudley]] of [[Roxbury, Massachusetts|Roxbury]] wrote in 1631 that the kings in the [[Massachusetts Bay|bay area]] were called sagamores, but were called sachems southward (in [[Plymouth, Massachusetts|Plymouth]]). The two terms apparently came from the same root. Although "sagamore" has sometimes been defined by colonists and historians as a subordinate lord (or subordinate chief{{cite book|title=Webster's New Collegiate Dictionary|page=1018|publisher=G. & C. Merriam Co|location=Springfield, Massachusetts|date=1973|isbn=0-87779-308-5}}), modern opinion is that "sachem" and "sagamore" are [[dialect]]ical variations of the same word.[http://www.hawthorneinsalem.org/Literature/NativeAmericans&Blacks/MainStreet/MMD666.html Life & Times: Squaw Sachem"], ''Hawthorne in Salem'', ''The Daily Times Chronicle'', Winchester Edition (MA), December 1999, accessed 27 Jan 2010
===Cognate words=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Family !Language !Word !Notes |- | rowspan="7" | Eastern Algonquian | Proto-Eastern Algonquian | ''*sākimāw'' | Reconstructed original |- | [[Lenape language|Lenape]] | ''sakima'' | derived from earlier form ''sakimaw''{{cite web |url=http://www.talk-lenape.org/detail.php?id=9092 |title=sakima |work=Lenape Talking Dictionary |accessdate=2011-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728081539/http://www.talk-lenape.org/detail.php?id=9092 |archivedate=2011-07-28 |df= }} |- | [[Narragansett language|Narragansett]] | ''sâchim'' | anglicized as ''sachem''Goddard, Ives (1978). "Eastern Algonquian languages", in "Northeast", ed. Bruce G. Trigger. Vol. 15 of Handbook of North American Indians, ed. William C. Sturtevant. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution, pg. 75 |- | [[Eastern Abnaki language|Eastern Abnaki]] | ''sakəma'' | anglicized as ''sagamore'' |- | [[Malecite-Passamaquoddy language|Malecite-Passamaquoddy]] | ''sakom'' | Francis, David A., Sr. et al. [http://www.lib.unb.ca/Texts/Maliseet/dictionary/ ''Maliseet - Passamaquoddy Dictionary'']. Mi'kmaq - Maliseet Institute |- | [[Western Abnaki language|Western Abnaki]] | ''sôgmô'' |Laurent, Joseph (1884) [http://www.canadiana.org/ECO/ItemRecord/08895?id=eb80654be91e3734 ''New familiar Abenakis and English dialogues the first ever published on the grammatical system''] |- |[[Wangunk]] |''sequin'' |{{Cite book|title=History of the Indians of Connecticut|last=De Forest|first=John William|publisher=|year=1852|isbn=|location=|pages=53}} |- |rowspan="9"| [[Central Algonquian languages|Central Algonquian]] | Proto-Central Algonquian | ''*hākimāw'' | Reconstructed original |- | [[Anishinaabe language|Anishinaabe]] | ''ogimaa'' | Nichols, John, and Earl Nyholm. (1995). ''A Concise Dictionary of Minnesota Ojibwe''. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press |- | [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] | ''ogimà'' | Mcgregor, Ernest. (1994). ''Algonquin Lexicon''. Maniwaki, QC: Kitigan Zibi Education Council. |- | [[Ottawa language|Ottawa]] | ''gimaa'' | Rhodes, Richard A. (1985). ''Eastern Ojibwa-Chippewa-Ottawa Dictionary''. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. |- | [[Potawatomi language|Potawatomi]] | ''wgema'' | anglicised as [[Ogema (disambiguation)|Ogema]] |- | [[Swampy Cree language|Eastern Swampy Cree]] | ''okimâw'' |MacKenzie, Marguerite (editor). (c2007). ''Wasaho Ininîwimowin Dictionary (Fort Severn Cree)''. Kwayaciiwin Education Resource Centre. |- | [[Northern East Cree language|Northern East Cree]] | ''uchimaa'' |Bobbish-Salt, Luci et al. (2004–06). ''Northern EastCree Dictionary''. Cree School Board. |- | [[Southern East Cree language|Southern East Cree]] | ''uchimaa'' |Neeposh, Ella et al. (2004–07). ''Southern EastCree Dictionary''. Cree School Board. |- | [[Naskapi language|Naskapi]] | ''iiyuuchimaaw'' | MacKenzie, Marguerite and Bill Jancewicz. (1994). [http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/naskapi/020011-150-e.php?uid=020011-nlc003120&uidc=recKey ''Naskapi lexicon''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527201931/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/naskapi/020011-150-e.php?uid=020011-nlc003120&uidc=recKey |date=2008-05-27 }}. Kawawachikamach, Quebec: Naskapi Development Corp. |} ==chiefs== {{see also|List of Native American leaders}} The "great chief" (Southern New England [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]]: ''massasoit sachem'') whose aid was such a boon to the [[Plymouth Colony]]—although his motives were complexSee Charles Mann, ''1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus''—is remembered today as simply [[Massasoit]].Note that this ''massa-'' element meaning "great" in the [[Massachusett language]] also appears in the name of the [[Massachusett]] (i.e. "Great Hills people") and subsequently in the name of the [[Commonwealth of Massachusetts]]. Another sachem, ''[[Mahomet Weyonomon]]'' of the ''[[Mohegan]]'' tribe, travelled to [[London]] in 1735, to petition King [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] for fairer treatment of his people. He complained that their lands were becoming overrun by [[English people|English]] settlers. Other sachems included [[Uncas]], [[Wonalancet]], [[Madockawando]], and [[Samoset]]. ==Clan Mother== ===Government and politics=== *[[Theodore Roosevelt]] named his home near [[Oyster Bay (town), New York|Oyster Bay, New York]] on [[Long Island]], [[Sagamore Hill]].{{cn|date=May 2014}} *"Sachem" was a title adopted by leaders of the Tammany societies, notably in [[Tammany Hall]] in New York City.{{cn|date=May 2014}} The eponymous [[Tamanend|Tammany]] was a sachem of the [[Lenape]]. A fraternal society arose out of the Tammany societies which was named the [[Improved Order of Red Men]], and to this day two of their national officers are known as the "Great Senior Sagamore" and the "Great Junior Sagamore."{{cite web|url=http://www.redmen.org/redmen/chiefs/|title=The Improved Order of Red Men|author=|date=|website=www.redmen.org}} *In the 1940s, the legislature of [[Indiana]] created the honorary title of "[[Sagamore of the Wabash]]", analogous to [[Kentucky Colonel]]. In 1996, the government designated "Sachem of the Wabash" as a higher honor.{{cite web|url=http://www.in.gov/gov/files/Update_Volume1_Issue26.pdf|title=Governor's press release announcing creation of the Sachem|author=|date=|website=in.gov}} ===Journalism=== * One of the oldest weekly newspapers in Canada is called ''The Grand River Sachem''. It has been publishing since 1856 and is located in [[Caledonia, Ontario]].{{cn|date=May 2014}} ===Literature=== *[[James Fenimore Cooper]] featured a character called "The Sagamore" in his novel ''[[The Last of the Mohicans]]''. *Rick, the protagonist of [[Simon Spurrier]]'s novel, ''The Culled'' (2006, book 1 of [[Abaddon Books#The Afterblight Chronicles|The Afterblight Chronicles]]), belongs to the [[Haudenosaunee]] people and is guided through crises by the sachem. Another character, named Hiawatha, saves Rick's life and advises him the [[Tadodaho]] have said Rick and Hiawatha's courses are "aligned".{{cite book|author=Spurrier, Simon|title=The Culled|publisher=[[Abaddon Books#The Afterblight Chronicles|Abaddon Books]]|date=2006|isbn=9781849970136|page=198}} *The 1838 poem "Sachem's-Wood"{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NcI3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA47&dq=sachem&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEYQ6AEwB2oVChMIw-Oe79vxxgIVBjI-Ch0gAAE-#v=onepage&q=sachem's-wood&f=false|title=The judgement. Sachem's-wood. Discourses: I. On the choice of an era in epic and tragic writing. II. On the relations of literature to a republican government. III. On the life and services of Lafayette. The hermit of Warkworth, by Bishop Percy|first=James Abraham|last=Hillhouse|date=23 May 2018|publisher=C. Little and J. Brown|via=Google Books}} by James Abraham Hillhouse (son of United States Senator [[James Hillhouse]]) describes the demise of the free sachem and his people. *There's a passage in ''[[Moby Dick]]'' by [[Herman Melville]], page 71, saying : " [...] where the loose hairy fibres waved to and fro like the topknot on some old Pottowattamie Sachem's head." ===Schools=== * [[Algonquin Regional High School]], in [[Northborough, MA]], named its art and poetry magazine ''Sachem'' after this Algonquin word.{{cn|date=May 2014}} * [[Laconia High School (New Hampshire)|Laconia High School]], in [[Laconia, NH]], refers to all of its athletic teams as the "Sachems".{{cn|date=May 2014}} * [[Middleborough High School]], in [[Middleboro, MA]], refers to all of its athletic teams as the "Sachems".{{cn|date=May 2014}} * [[Pentucket Regional High School]], in [[West Newbury, MA]], refers to all of its athletic teams as the "Sachems".{{cite web|url=https://www.alumniclass.com/pentucket|title=Pentucket Regional High School Sachems Alumni - West Newbury Massachusetts MA|first=AlumniClass.com - 2018 - all rights|last=reserved|date=|website=www.alumniclass.com}} * [[Saugus High School (Massachusetts)|Saugus High School]], in [[Saugus, MA]], refers to all of its athletic teams as the "Sachems".{{cn|date=December 2014}} * [[Winchester High School (Massachusetts)|Winchester High School]], Massachusetts, refers to all of its athletic teams as the "Sachems".{{cn|date=May 2014}} * [[RHAM High School]], in [[Hebron, CT]], refers to all of its athletic teams as the "Sachems".{{cn|date=May 2014}} == References == {{Refbegin}} {{Refend}} {{Reflist|refs= {{cite book | title=[[American Heritage Dictionary]] | year=2000 | publisher=Houghton Mifflin |edition=4th | chapter=sachem | chapter-url= http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/sachem }} {{cite book | title=[[American Heritage Dictionary]] | year=2000 | publisher=Houghton Mifflin |edition=4th | chapter=sagamore | chapter-url= http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/sagamore}} {{cite web | url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sachem | title=sachem | work=Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary | publisher=Merriam-Webster Online | accessdate=2009-11-09}} {{cite web | url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sagamore | title=sagamore | work=Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary | publisher=Merriam-Webster Online |accessdate=2009-11-09}} }} ==External links== {{wiktionary|sachem}} {{wiktionary|sagamore}} [[Category:Algonquian peoples]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of the Northeastern Woodlands]] [[Category:Titles and offices of Native American leaders]] [[Category:Tribal chiefs|*]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Steven M. Greer | image = StevenGreer01.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|06|28}} | birth_place = [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = [[Physician]] (retired)
[[Ufology|UFOlogist]] }} '''Steven Macon Greer''' (June 28, 1955) is an American retired [[Traumatology|traumatologist]] and [[Ufology|ufologist]] who founded the [[Center for the Study of Extraterrestrial Intelligence]] (CSETI) and the Disclosure Project, which seeks the [[UFO conspiracy theory#Disclosure|disclosure of allegedly suppressed UFO information]]. ==Early life== Greer was born in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] in 1955. He claims to have seen an [[unidentified flying object]] at [[Close encounter|close range]] when he was about eight years old, which inspired his interest in [[ufology]].{{cite news | first = Keith | last = Thompson | title = If We Call Them, Will They Come? | newspaper = [[Yoga Journal]] | pages = 70–77, 1–154 | date = October 1989 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=eOkDAAAAMBAJ&hl=ja&pg=PA70#v=onepage&q | access-date = 8 March 2013 | quote="page 70: By day, he is chairman of the Department of Emergency Medicine at a medium-sized hospital, frequently on call for periods of 12 to 24 hours." }} Greer was trained as a [[Transcendental Meditation]] teacher and served as director of a meditation organization.{{cite news | authorlink = Alexander S. Heard | first=Alexander S. | last= Heard | title = Alien douglas brothers, come on down! | journal = [[Outside (magazine)|Outside]] | date = 1 September 1994 | url = http://www.outsideonline.com/outdoor-adventure/Alien-Brothers--Come-on-Down-.html | access-date = 12 March 2013 }} He received his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in [[biology]] from [[Appalachian State University]] in 1982https://www.linkedin.com/in/steven-greer-a3b48351 and [[M.D.]] from the [[East Tennessee State University James H. Quillen College of Medicine|James H. Quillen College of Medicine]] of [[East Tennessee State University]] in 1987.[http://www.vahealthprovider.com/results_cert.asp?License_No=0101057732 Steven Macon Greer] Virginia Board of Medicine, accessed Jan 20, 2013 He attended MAHEC [[University of North Carolina]] where he completed his internship in 1988 and received his Virginia medical license in 1989. That year he became a member of the [[Alpha Omega Alpha]] Honor Medical Society.{{cite book | title=The Pharos of Alpha Omega Alpha - Volume 50 | publisher=Alpha Omega Alpha | year=1987 | author=Author Unknown | page=54}}"College of Medlclne — Oelta of Tennessee Class of I987: Steven Macon Greer"{{cite web | url=http://www.alphaomegaalpha.org/search.php | title=Locate A Member | publisher=Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Medical Society | access-date=March 11, 2013 | author=Unknown author | pages=Use the search term: Greer to yield this result: Steven Macon Greer 115–R–1987–0069199}}{{cite web | url=http://com.etsu.edu/default.asp?V_DOC_ID=1995 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060908010936/http://com.etsu.edu/default.asp?V_DOC_ID=1995 | archivedate=2006-09-08 | title=AOA Members from James H. Quillen College of Medicine | publisher=Quillen College of Medicine | author=Unknown author}} ==Career== {{Main|Center for the Study of Extraterrestrial Intelligence}} Greer founded the Center for the Study of Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence (CSETI) in 1990 to create a diplomatic and research-based initiative to contact [[Extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrial]] civilizations.{{cite web | title=They're Here; UFO watchers to reveal proof that aliens have visited Earth | publisher=The Daily Record | date=May 9, 2001 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-74321804.html}} In 1993, he founded the Disclosure Project, a nonprofit research project, whose goal is to disclose to the public the government's alleged knowledge of UFOs, extraterrestrial intelligence, and advanced energy and propulsion systems.{{cite book | title = Life With a Cosmos Clearance | first1 = Daniel M | last1 = Salter | first2 = Nancy | last2 = Red Star | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=KUqLKSWPrvQC&pg=PA1 | publisher = Light Technology Publishing | year = 2003 | isbn = 1891824376 | pages = x–ix, 1–4 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.disclosureproject.org/ | title = The Disclosure Project Website | year = 2010 | publisher = The Disclosure Project | access-date = 7 March 2013 | quote = "The Disclosure Project is a research project working to fully disclose the facts about UFOs, extraterrestrial intelligence, and classified advanced energy and propulsion systems." }}{{cite news | last = Tudor | first = Silke | title = Alien Culture | newspaper = [[SF Weekly]] | date = 26 September 2001 | url = http://www.sfweekly.com/2001-09-26/news/alien-culture/ | access-date = 10 March 2013 }} The Disclosure Project was founded in an effort to grant amnesty to government whistle-blowers willing to violate their security oaths by sharing insider knowledge about UFOs.{{cite news | title = Admiral: Never looked for UFO data | last = Cox | first = Billy | url = http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20080806/blog32/525095430 | newspaper = [[Sarasota Herald-Tribune|Herald Tribune]] | date = 6 August 2008 | access-date = 2013-03-21 }} Greer says he gave a briefing to [[Director of Central Intelligence|CIA director]] [[R. James Woolsey, Jr.|James Woolsey]] at a dinner party, although this was denied by director Woolsey and attendees.{{cite web|url=http://www.ufowatchdog.com/greer_letter.htm|title=Greer Letter|website=www.ufowatchdog.com|access-date=2016-05-10}}{{cite web|url=http://siriusdisclosure.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/1999-Woolsey-Petersen-letter.pdf|title=Rebuttal letter to Greer|last=Woolsey|first=James|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} In October 1994, Greer appeared in [[Larry King]]'s TV special ''The UFO Coverup?''{{cite news | last = Mendoza | first = Manuel | title = Alien Obsession Hits Even Larry King | newspaper = [[The Wichita Eagle]] | date = 10 October 1994 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WE&s_site=kansas&p_multi=WE&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADB63AF20E2DA6&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | access-date = 8 March 2013 | archiveurl = http://nbgoku23.googlepages.com/ALIENOBSESSIONHITSEVENLARRYKING.htm | archivedate = 2007-05-12 }} In 1995, Greer worked as a physician at the department of emergency medicine at [[Caldwell Memorial Hospital]],{{cite news | title = Asheville physician's hobby is chasing extraterrestrials | first = Britt | last = Nelson | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XjcfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K88EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7002,2766210 | newspaper = Herald-Journal | date = 23 April 1994 | access-date = 8 March 2013 }} where he was chairman. In 1997, Greer, along with other members of CSETI, including Apollo astronaut [[Edgar Mitchell]], made a presentation at a background briefing for members of [[United States Congress|Congress]].{{cite news | title = The Unending Search for UFOs | first = Mary | last = Lord | url = https://www.usnews.com/usnews/culture/articles/970414/archive_006675.htm | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509083000/http://www.usnews.com/usnews/culture/articles/970414/archive_006675.htm | archivedate= 9 May 2013 | newspaper = [[U.S. News & World Report]] | date = 14 April 1997 | access-date = 27 November 2015 }}'' '' In 1998, Greer gave up his career as an emergency room physician in favor of the Disclosure Project.{{cite web | title=Founder of UFO Project is Coming to Portland | publisher=[[The Columbian]] | date=Sep 11, 2001 | access-date=March 10, 2013 | author=Oppegard, Brett| url=http://www.columbian.com/ | archiveurl=http://www.mysticbroadcast.net/ndn/columbian.html | archivedate=September 11, 2001}}{{cite web | title=Doctor UFO | publisher=Internal Medicine News | date=Dec 1, 2001 | access-date=March 10, 2013 | author=Berger, Joanne | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Doctor+UFO.+(Indications).-a080899504 | archiveurl=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-81217718.html | archivedate=Dec 1, 2001}} In May 2001, Greer held a press conference at the [[National Press Club (United States)|National Press Club]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] that featured 20 retired Air Force, [[Federal Aviation Administration]] and intelligence officers.{{cite news | title = Government is covering up UFO evidence, group says | first = Julia | last = Duin | url = http://www.washtimes.com/national/20010510-19816390.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20010516132431/http://www.washtimes.com/national/20010510-19816390.htm | archivedate = 2001-05-16 | newspaper = [[The Washington Times]] | date = 11 May 2001 | access-date = 8 March 2013 }}{{cite news | title = Group Calls for Disclosure of UFO Info | author = Katelynn Raymer | author2 = David Ruppe | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=98572 | newspaper = [[ABC News]] | date = 10 May 2001 | access-date = 11 March 2013 }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/1322432.stm|title=UFO spotters slam 'US cover-up'|publisher=BBC News|date=May 10, 2001}}{{cite web | last =Kehnemui | first =Sharon | title =Men in Suits See Aliens as Part of Solution, Not Problem | work=[[Fox News]] | date=May 10, 2001 | url =http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,24364,00.html | access-date = 2007-05-10 }}{{cite web | last =McCullagh | first =Declan | authorlink =Declan McCullagh | title =Ooo-WEE-ooo Fans Come to D.C. |work=Wired News | date =May 10, 2001 | url =http://archive.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2001/05/43526 | access-date = 2007-05-10 }} According to a 2002 report in the ''[[Daily Emerald|Oregon Daily Emerald]]'', Greer has gathered 120 hours of testimony from civilians and various government and military officials, including astronaut [[Gordon Cooper]] and a [[brigadier general]], on the topic of UFOs.{{cite news | title = Alien theorist offers proof of government coverup | last = Schmidt | first = Brad | url = http://dailyemerald.com/2002/04/25/alien-theorist-offers-proof-of-government-coverup/ | newspaper = [[Daily Emerald|Oregon Daily Emerald]] | date = 25 April 2002 | access-date = 2012-12-12 }} Greer authored "Unacknowledged: An Exposé of the World's Greatest Secret” in 2017. The book is also the subject of a 2017 Documentary film, titled "Unacknowledged," directed by Michael Mazzola. ==''Sirius''== In 2013, Greer co-produced ''[[Sirius (2013 film)|Sirius]]'', a documentary detailing his work and hypotheses regarding extraterrestrial life, government cover-ups and [[Close encounter|close encounters of the fifth kind]].{{cite web|last=Sullivan|first=Paul|title=New documentary proves aliens exist. We're dead Sirius|url=http://metronews.ca/voices/just-saying/627672/new-documentary-proves-aliens-exist-were-dead-sirius/|publisher=Metro News|access-date=6 December 2013}} The film was directed by [[Amar Kaleka|Amardeep Kaleka]] and narrated by [[Thomas Jane]], and covers Greer's 2006 book ''Hidden Truth, Forbidden Knowledge''. The movie premiered on April 22, 2013, in Los Angeles, California, and features interviews from former government and military officials.{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/tiny-alien-humanoid-claimed-exist-steven-greers-upcoming-documentary-sirius-photo-video-1181439 |title=Tiny Alien Humanoid Claimed To Exist In Steven Greer's documentary 'Sirius' [PHOTO, VIDEO] |publisher=Ibtimes.com |date=2013-04-09 |access-date=2013-04-24}} ''Sirius'' depicts a six-inch human skeleton known as the [[Atacama skeleton]], and features images and a DNA test of the skeleton.{{cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/space/ufo-film-to-provide-proof-that-aliens-exist_841077.html |title=UFO film to provide proof that aliens exist |publisher=Zeenews.india.com |date=2013-04-10 |access-date=2013-04-24}}{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.scienceworldreport.com/articles/6119/20130409/ufo-film-provide-proof-tiny-extraterrestrial-aliens-six-inch-body.htm |title=UFO Film May Provide Proof of Tiny Extraterrestrial Aliens: Six Inch Body Dissected (Video) : Space |publisher=Science World Report |date=2013-04-09 |access-date=2013-04-24}} Genetic evidence showed that it was human, with genetic markers found in "indigenous women from the Chilean region of South America". The director of the center that did the analysis said, "It's an interesting medical mystery of an unfortunate human with a series of birth defects that currently [...] the genetics of which are not obvious."{{cite news|url=http://www.medicaldaily.com/atacama-humanoid-human-researchers-say-245416 |title='Atacama Humanoid is Human, Researchers Say' |publisher=[[IBT Media#Brands|Medical Daily]] |date=2013-05-01 |access-date=2013-09-09}}{{cite news|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2013/05/bizarre-6-inch-skeleton-shown-to.html |title=Bizarre 6-Inch Skeleton Shown to Be Human |work=Science magazine, column 'Science Now' |publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS) |date=2013-05-03 |access-date=2013-09-08}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Steven M. Greer}} * [http://www.disclosureproject.org/presskit/sgbio.shtml Steven Greer biography] at the Disclosure Project * {{IMDb name|2806853}} {{UFOs}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Greer, Steven M.}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American traumatologists]] [[Category:American UFO writers]] [[Category:Contactees]] [[Category:Ufologists]] [[Category:Appalachian State University alumni]] [[Category:East Tennessee State University alumni]] [[Category:People from Charlottesville, Virginia]] [[Category:Writers from Charlotte, North Carolina]]

{{Infobox person | name = Tad Lincoln | image = Tad Lincoln in uniform.jpg | image_size = | caption = Lincoln wearing a military-style uniform, c. 1864 | birth_name = Thomas Lincoln III | birth_date = {{birth date|1853|4|4}} | birth_place = [[Springfield, Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1871|7|15|1853|4|4}} | death_place = [[Chicago]], Illinois, U.S. | resting_place = [[Lincoln Tomb]] at [[Oak Ridge Cemetery]] | education = Elizabeth Street School | parents = [[Abraham Lincoln]]
[[Mary Todd Lincoln]] | relatives = See [[Lincoln family tree]] or [[Edward Baker Lincoln]] (brother), [[Robert Todd Lincoln]] (brother), [[William Wallace Lincoln]] (brother) }} '''Thomas "Tad" Lincoln III''' (April 4, 1853 – July 15, 1871) was the fourth and youngest son of [[Abraham Lincoln|Abraham]] and [[Mary Todd Lincoln]]. The nickname "Tad" was given to him by his father, who observed that he had a large head and was "as wiggly as a tadpole" when he was a baby. Lincoln was known to be impulsive and unrestrained, and he did not attend school during his father's lifetime. He had free run of the [[White House]], and there are stories of him interrupting presidential meetings, collecting animals, and charging visitors to see his father. He died at the age of 18 on July 15, 1871, in [[Chicago]]. ==Early life and education== Lincoln was born on April 4, 1853,Manning (2016), page 75 the fourth son of [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Mary Todd Lincoln|Mary Todd]]. His three elder brothers were [[Robert Todd Lincoln|Robert]] (1843–1926), [[Edward Baker Lincoln|Edward]] (1846–1850), and [[William Wallace Lincoln|William]] (1850–1862).{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} Named after his paternal grandfather [[Thomas Lincoln]] and uncle Thomas Lincoln, Jr., the fourth boy was soon nicknamed "Tad" by his father, for his small body and large head, and because he wiggled like a [[tadpole]] as an infant.Wead (2003), pp. 89–90.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iCSNCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Father Lincoln: The Untold Story of Abraham Lincoln and His Boys--Robert, Eddy, Willie, and Tad|last=Manning|first=Alan|date=2016-05-01|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9781493018246|language=en}} Lincoln's first name has occasionally been erroneously recorded as Thaddeus.Bayne (2001), p. 13 Lincoln was born with a form of [[cleft lip and palate]], causing him speech problems throughout his life. He had a [[lisp]] and delivered his words rapidly and unintelligibly.Hutchinson (2009), para. 2. Often only those close to Lincoln were able to understand him.Hutchinson (2009), para. 11.Bayne (2001), p. 3. For example, he called his father's bodyguard, [[William H. Crook]], "Took", and his father "Papa Day" instead of "Papa Dear".Hutchinson (2009), para. 16. The cleft palate contributed to uneven teeth; he had such difficulty chewing food that his meals were specially prepared.Hutchinson (2009), para. 22. Lincoln and his brother Willie were considered "notorious hellions" during the period they lived in Springfield. They were recorded by their father's law partner [[William Herndon (lawyer)|William Herndon]] as having turned their law office upside down, pulling the books off the shelves, while their father appeared oblivious to their behavior.Wead (2003), p. 90. ==White House years== [[File:A&TLincoln.jpg|thumb|Tad Lincoln with his father looking at a photo album]] Upon their father's election as President, both Tad and Willie moved into the White House and it became their new playground and home. At the request of Mrs. Lincoln, [[Julia Taft Bayne|Julia Taft]] brought her younger brothers, 14-year-old "Bud" (Horatio Nelson Taft Jr., 1847–1915) and 12-year-old "Holly" (Halsey Cook Taft, 1849–1897), to the White House, and they became playmates of the two young Lincolns.Wead (2003), p. 91.Bayne (2001), pp. 1–3. In February 1862, both Lincoln boys contracted [[typhoid fever]] and both boys were bedridden. Willie died on February 20, while Tad recovered. After his brother's death, his parents became even more lenient toward his behavior.Wead (2003), pp. 91–92. During the time his father was alive, Tad was impulsive, unrestrained, and did not attend school. [[John Hay]] wrote that the boy's numerous tutors in the White House usually quit in frustration. Tad had free run of the White House, and there are stories of him interrupting presidential meetings, collecting animals, charging visitors to see his father, and more.{{cite web |author=R. J. Brown Editor-in-Chief |url=http://www.historyreference.org/library/reftad.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304130505/http://www.historyreference.org/library/reftad.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 4, 2016 |title=R. J. Brown. Tad Lincoln: The Not-so-Famous Son of A Most-Famous President |publisher=Historybuff.com |accessdate=June 18, 2013 }} On April 14, 1865, Tad went to [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|Grover's Theatre]] to see the play ''Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp'' while his parents attended the performance of ''[[Our American Cousin]]'' at [[Ford's Theatre]]. That night, his father was [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln|fatally shot]] by [[John Wilkes Booth]]. When news of the assassination spread to Grover's Theatre, the manager made an announcement to the entire audience. Tad began running and screaming, "They killed Papa! They killed Papa!" He was escorted back to the White House while his mother pleaded to have him brought to his father's deathbed at the [[Petersen House]]. "Bring Tad—he will speak to Tad—he loves him so." Late that night, an inconsolable Tad was put to bed by a White House doorman.Wead (2003), p. 93. President Lincoln died the next morning, on Saturday, April 15, at 7:22 am.{{cite journal|title=How Did Lincoln Die?|journal=American Heritage|date=February–March 1995|volume=46|issue=1|url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/how-did-lincoln-die?page=show|author=Richard A. R. Fraser, MD}} About the death of his father, Tad said:
Pa is dead. I can hardly believe that I shall never see him again. I must learn to take care of myself now. Yes, Pa is dead, and I am only Tad Lincoln now, little Tad, like other little boys. I am not a president's son now. I won't have many presents anymore. Well, I will try and be a good boy, and will hope to go someday to Pa and brother Willie, in Heaven.Wead (2003), pp. 93–94.
==Later life== After the assassination, Mary, Robert, and Tad Lincoln lived together in Chicago. Robert moved out after a short time, and Tad began attending school. In 1868, they left Chicago and lived in Europe for almost three years, in Germany and later in England.{{cite book|last=Emerson|first=Jason|title=Giant in the Shadows: The Life of Robert T. Lincoln|year=2012|publisher=SIU (Southern Illinois University) Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tPqgC3RS-7sC&pg=PA152#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} Lincoln suffered from what one modern commentator has called a "complex speech and language disorder" related to some form of a cleft lip or palate. This caused some problems when Lincoln was in school in Chicago. While at the [[Elizabeth Street School (Chicago)|Elizabeth Street School]], his schoolmates sometimes called him "Stuttering Tad" because of the speech impediment,{{cite journal|last=Hutchinson|first=John M.|title=What Was Tad Lincoln's Speech Problem?|journal=Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association|date=Winter 2009|volume=30|issue=1|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=jala;view=text;rgn=main;idno=2629860.0030.105|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} which he was able to overcome as a teenager. ==Death== On Saturday morning, July 15, 1871, Lincoln died at the age of 18.{{cite web|title=Abraham Lincoln and Chicago (Abraham Lincoln's Classroom)|url=http://www.abrahamlincolnsclassroom.org/Library/newsletter.asp?ID=60&CRLI=140|publisher=The Lincoln Institute|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} The cause of death has been variously referred to as [[tuberculosis]],{{cite book|last=Davenport|first=Don|title=In Lincoln's Footsteps: A Historical Guide to the Lincoln Sites in Illinois|year=2001|publisher=Big Earth Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rz3VkkikvngC&pg=PA210#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=210}} a [[Pleurisy|pleuristic]] attack,Emerson, Jason. Giant in the Shadows: The Life of Robert T. Lincoln. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 2012, P. 478. [[pneumonia]], or [[congestive heart failure]].{{cite web|title=The Lincoln Boys|url=https://www.loc.gov/item/sm1874.15788/|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}{{cite book|last=Emerson|first=Jason|title=Giant in the Shadows:The Life of Robert T. Lincoln|year=2012|publisher=SIU (Southern Illinois University) Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tPqgC3RS-7sC&pg=PA478#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=478|quote=With serious effusion compressing the lungs and crowding the nearby heart, there was not enough oxygen to maintain the life centers of the brain}} (quoting Milton Shutes, "Mortality of the Five Lincoln Boys", ''Lincoln Herald'', vol. 57 (Spring 1955), p. 7.) Lincoln's death occurred at the Clifton House hotel in Chicago.Davenport, Page 153 In an obituary, [[John Hay]] affectionately referred to him as "Little Tad".{{cite book|last=Hay|first=John|title=At Lincoln's Side: John Hay's Civil War Correspondence and Selected Writings|year=1871|publisher=SIU (Southern Illinois University) Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I_W1CyzcPTIC&pg=PA111#v=onepage&q&f=false|editor=Michael Burlingame (2006)|accessdate=December 2, 2012|page=111}} Funeral services were held for Lincoln in his brother Robert's home in Chicago. His body was transported to Springfield and buried in the [[Lincoln Tomb]] at [[Oak Ridge Cemetery]], alongside his father and two of his brothers. Robert accompanied the casket on the train, but Mary was too distraught to make the trip.Davenport, pages 153 –154 ==Screen Portrayals== On film and television Tad Lincoln has been portrayed by, * Newton Hall in ''[[The Dramatic Life of Abraham Lincoln]]'' (1924) * Gordon Thorpe in ''[[Abraham Lincoln (1930 film)|Abraham Lincoln]]'' (1930) * [[Dickie Moore (actor)|Dickie Moore]] in ''Lincoln in the White House'' (1939, Short) * Henry Blair in ''[[Abe Lincoln in Illinois (film)|Abe Lincoln in Illinois]]'' (1940) * John Levin in ''Lincoln'' (1974) * Troy Sweeney in ''[[Lincoln (miniseries)|Lincoln]]'' (1988) * [[Adam Lamberg]] in ''[[The Day Lincoln Was Shot]]'' (1998) * [[Gulliver McGrath]] in ''[[Lincoln (film)|Lincoln]]'' (2012) * [[Joshua Rush]] in ''[[Saving Lincoln]]'' (2013) * Benjamin Perkinson in ''[[Killing Lincoln (film)|Killing Lincoln]]'' (2013) ==See also== * [[Lincoln family tree]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="Note"}} == References == {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|isbn=0-8032-6191-8|oclc=248170310|title=Tad Lincoln's Father|authorlink=Julia Taft Bayne|last1=Bayne|first1=Julia Taft|last2=DeCredico|first2=Mary A|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|edition=First Bison Books|location=Lincoln|year=2001}} * {{cite journal|last=Hutchinson|first=John M.|date=Winter 2009|title=What Was Tad Lincoln's Speech Problem?|journal=Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association|volume=30|issue=1|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=|issn=|pmid=|pmc= |doi=|bibcode=|oclc=|id=|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jala/2629860.0030.105/--what-was-tad-lincolns-speech-problem?rgn=main;view=fulltext;q1=speech+problem|accessdate=July 22, 2011}} * {{cite book|isbn=|oclc=9448054|title=Lincoln's Sons|last=Randall|first=Ruth Painter|publisher=Little, Brown|location=Boston|year=1955}} * {{cite book|isbn=0-7434-4631-3|oclc=51616758|title=All The
